subsections.content: Cladding shall be specified and installed in accordance with Chapter 14and the cladding manufacturer’s installation instructions or an approved design. Foam sheathing shall be attached to masonry or concrete construction in accordance with the insulation manufacturer’s installation instructions or an approved design. Furring and furring attachments through foam sheathing shall be designed to resist design loads determined in accordance with Chapter 16, including support of cladding weight as applicable. Fasteners used to attach cladding or furring through foam sheathing to masonry or concrete substrates shall be approved for application into masonry or concrete material and shall be installed in accordance with the fastener manufacturer’s installation instructions.

subsections.title: 2603.12Cladding attachment over foam sheathing to cold-formed steel framing.
subsections.content: Cladding shall be specified and installed in accordance with Chapter 14and the cladding manufacturer’s approved installation instructions, including any limitations for use over foam plastic sheathing, or an approved design. Where used, furring and furring attachments shall be designed to resist design loads determined in accordance with Chapter 16. In addition, the cladding orfurring attachments through foam sheathing to cold-formed steelframing shall meet or exceed the minimum fastening requirements of Sections 2603.12.1and 2603.12.2, or an approved design for support of cladding weight.

subsubsections.title: 2603.12.1Direct attachment.
subsubsections.content: Where cladding is installed directly over foam sheathing without the use of furring, cladding minimum fastening requirements to support the cladding weight shall be as specified in Table 2603.12.1.

subsubsections.title: 2603.12.2Furred cladding attachment.
subsubsections.content: Where steel or wood furring is used to attach cladding over foam sheathing, furring minimum fastening requirements to support the cladding weight shall be as specified in Table 2603.12.2. Where placed horizontally, wood furring shall be preservative-treated wood in accordance with Section 2303.1.9or naturally durable wood and fasteners shall be corrosion resistant in accordance Section 2304.10.5. Steel furring shall have a minimum G60 galvanized coating.

subsections.title: 2603.13Cladding attachment over foam sheathing to wood framing.
subsections.content: Cladding shall be specified and installed in accordance with Chapter 14and the cladding manufacturer’s installation instructions. Where used, furring and furring attachments shall be designed to resist design loads determined in accordance with Chapter 16. In addition, the cladding or furring attachments through foam sheathing to framing shall meet or exceed the minimum fastening requirements of Section 2603.13.1or 2603.13.2, or an approved design for support of cladding weight.

subsubsections.title: 2603.13.1Direct attachment.
subsubsections.content: Where cladding is installed directly over foam sheathing without the use of furring, minimum fastening requirements to support the cladding weight shall be as specified in Table 2603.13.1.

subsubsections.title: 2603.13.2Furred cladding attachment.
subsubsections.content: Where wood furring is used to attach cladding over foam sheathing, furring minimum fastening requirements to support the cladding weight shall be as specified in Table 2603.13.2. Where placed horizontally, wood furring shall be preservative-treated wood in accordance with Section 2303.1.9or naturally durable wood and fasteners shall be corrosion resistant in accordance with Section 2304.10.5.

sections.section: SECTION BC 2604 INTERIOR FINISH AND TRIM

subsections.title: 2604.1General.
subsections.content: Plastic materials installed as interior finish ortrimshall comply with Chapter 8. Foam plastics shall only be installed as interior finish where approved in accordance with the special provisions of Section 2603.9. Foam plastics that are used as interior finish shall meet the flame spread and smoke-developed index requirements for interior finish in accordance with Chapter 8. Foam plastics installed as interiortrimshall comply with Section 2604.2.

subsubsections.title: 2604.1.1Plenums.
subsubsections.content: Foam plastics installed in plenums as interior wall or ceiling finish shall comply with Section 2603.7. Foam plastics installed in plenums as interior trim shall comply with Sections 2604.2and 2603.7.

subsections.title: [F]2604.2Interior trim.
subsections.content: Foam plastic used as interiortrimshall comply with Sections 2604.2.1through 2604.2.4.

subsubsections.title: [F]2604.2.1Density.
subsubsections.content: The minimum density of the interiortrimshall be 20 pcf (320 kg/m3).

subsubsections.title: [F]2604.2.2Thickness.
subsubsections.content: The maximum thickness of the interiortrimshall be1/2inch (12.7 mm) and the maximum width shall be 8 inches (204 mm).

subsubsections.title: [F]2604.2.3Area limitation.
subsubsections.content: The interiortrimshall not constitute more than 10 percent of the specific wall or ceiling areas to which it is attached.

subsubsections.title: [F]2604.2.4Flame spread.
subsubsections.content: The flame spread index shall not exceed 75 where tested in accordance with ASTM E84or UL 723. The smoke-developed index shall not be limited.

subsections.title: 2605.1Interior use.
subsections.content: Where used within a building, plastic veneer shall comply with the interior finish requirements of Chapter 8.

subsections.title: 2605.2Exterior use.
subsections.content: Exterior plastic veneer, other than plastic siding, shall be permitted to be installed on theexterior wallsof buildings of any type of construction in accordance with all of the following requirements:

subsections.title: 2605.3Plastic siding.
subsections.content: Plastic siding shall comply with the requirements of Sections 1403and 1404.

subsections.title: 2606.1General.
subsections.content: The provisions of this section and Sections 2607through 2611shall govern the quality and methods of application of light-transmitting plastics for use as light-transmitting materials in buildings and structures. Foam plastics shall comply with Section 2603. Light-transmitting plastic materials that meet the other code requirements for walls and roofs shall be permitted to be used in accordance with the other applicable chapters of the code.

subsections.title: 2606.2Approval for use.
subsections.content: Sufficient technical data shall be submitted to substantiate the proposed use of any light-transmitting material, as approved by thebuilding officialand subject to the requirements of this section.

subsections.title: 2606.3Identification.
subsections.content: Each unit or package of light-transmitting plastic shall be identified with amarkor decal satisfactory to thebuilding official, which includes identification as to the material classification.

subsections.title: 2606.4Specifications.
subsections.content: Light-transmitting plastics, including thermoplastic, thermosetting or reinforced thermosetting plastic material, shall have a self-ignition temperature of 650°F (343°C) or greater where tested in accordance with ASTM D1929; a smoke-developed index not greater than 450 where tested in the manner intended for use in accordance with ASTM E84or UL 723, or a maximum average smoke density rating not greater than 75 where tested in the thickness intended for use in accordance with ASTM D2843and shall conform to one of the following combustibility classifications:

subsections.title: 2606.5Structural requirements.
subsections.content: Light-transmitting plastic materials in their assembly shall be of adequate strength and durability to withstand the loads indicated in Chapter 16. Technical data shall be submitted to establish stresses, maximum unsupported spans and such other information for the various thicknesses and forms used as deemed necessary by thebuilding official.

subsections.title: 2606.6Fastening.
subsections.content: Fastening shall be adequate to withstand the loads in Chapter 16. Proper allowance shall be made for expansion and contraction of light-transmitting plastic materials in accordance with accepted data on the coefficient of expansion of the material and other material in conjunction with which it is employed.

subsections.title: 2606.7Light-diffusing systems.
subsections.content: Unless the building is equipped throughout with anautomatic sprinkler systemin accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, light-diffusing systems shall not be installed in the following occupancies and locations:

subsubsections.title: 2606.7.1Support.
subsubsections.content: Light-transmitting plastic diffusers shall be supported directly or indirectly from ceiling or roof construction by use of noncombustible hangers. Hangers shall be not less than No. 12 steel-wire gage (0.106 inch) galvanized wire or equivalent.

subsubsections.title: 2606.7.2Installation.
subsubsections.content: Light-transmitting plastic diffusers shall comply with Chapter 8unless the light-transmitting plastic diffusers will fall from the mountings before igniting, at an ambient temperature of not less than 200°F (111°C) below the ignition temperature of the panels. The panels shall remain in place at an ambient room temperature of 175°F (79°C) for a period of not less than 15 minutes.

subsubsections.title: 2606.7.3Size limitations.
subsubsections.content: Individual panels or units shall not exceed 10 feet (3048 mm) in length nor 30 square feet (2.79 m2) in area.

subsubsections.title: 2606.7.4Fire suppression system.
subsubsections.content: In buildings that are equipped throughout with anautomatic sprinkler systemin accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, plastic light-diffusing systems shall be protected both above and below unless the sprinkler system has been specifically approved for installation only above the light-diffusing system. Areas of light-diffusing systems that are protected in accordance with this section shall not be limited.

subsubsections.title: 2606.7.5Electrical luminaires.
subsubsections.content: Light-transmitting plastic panels and light-diffuser panels that are installed in approved electrical luminaires shall comply with the requirements of Chapter 8unless the light-transmitting plastic panels conform to the requirements of Section 2606.7.2. The area of approved light-transmitting plastic materials that is used in requiredexitsorcorridorsshall not exceed 30 percent of the aggregate area of the ceiling in which such panels are installed, unless the building is equipped throughout with anautomatic sprinkler systemin accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.

subsections.title: 2606.8Partitions.
subsections.content: Light-transmitting plastics used in or as partitions shall comply with the requirements of Chapters 6and 8.

subsections.title: 2606.9Bathroom accessories.
subsections.content: Light-transmitting plastics shall be permitted as glazing in shower stalls, shower doors, bathtub enclosures and similar accessory units. Safety glazing shall be provided in accordance with Chapter 24.

subsections.title: 2606.10Awnings, patio covers and similar structures.
subsections.content: Awningsconstructed of light-transmitting plastics shall be constructed in accordance with the provisions specified in Section 3105and Chapter 32for projections. Patio covers constructed of light-transmitting plastics shall comply with Section 2606. Light-transmitting plastics used in canopies at motor fuel-dispensing facilities shall comply with Section 2606, except as modified by Section 406.7.2.

subsections.title: 2606.11Greenhouses.
subsections.content: Light-transmitting plastics shall be permitted in lieu of glass in greenhouses.

subsections.title: 2606.12Solar collectors.
subsections.content: Light-transmitting plastic covers on solar collectors having noncombustible sides and bottoms shall be permitted on buildings not over threestories above grade planeor 9,000 square feet (836.1 m2) in total floor area, provided that the light-transmitting plastic cover does not exceed 33.33 percent of the roof area for CC1 materials or 25 percent of the roof area for CC2 materials.

sections.section: SECTION BC 2607 LIGHT-TRANSMITTING PLASTIC WALL PANELS

subsections.title: 2607.1General.
subsections.content: Light-transmitting plastics shall not be used as wall panels inexterior wallsin occupancies in Groups A-l, A-2, H, I-2 and I-3. In other groups, light-transmitting plastics shall be permitted to be used as wall panels inexterior walls, provided that the walls are not required to have a fire-resistance rating and the installation conforms to the requirements of this section. Such panels shall be erected and anchored on a foundation, waterproofed or otherwise protected from moisture absorption and sealed with a coat of mastic or other approved waterproof coating. Light-transmitting plastic wall panels shall comply with Section 2606.

subsections.title: 2607.2Installation.
subsections.content: Exterior wallpanels installed as provided for herein shall not alter the type of construction classification of the building.

subsections.title: 2607.3Height limitation.
subsections.content: Light-transmitting plastics shall not be installed more than 75 feet (22 860 mm) abovegrade plane, except as allowed by Section 2607.5.

subsections.title: 2607.4Area limitation and separation.
subsections.content: The maximum area of a single wall panel and minimum vertical and horizontal separation requirements for exterior light-transmitting plastic wall panels shall be as provided for in Table 2607.4. The maximum percentage of wall area of anystoryin light-transmitting plastic wall panels shall not exceed that indicated in Table 2607.4or the percentage of unprotected openings permitted by Section 705.8, whichever is smaller.

subsections.title: 2607.5Automatic sprinkler system.
subsections.content: Where the building is equipped throughout with anautomatic sprinkler systemin accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, the maximum percentage area ofexterior wallin anystoryin light-transmitting plastic wall panels and the maximum square footage of a single area given in Table 2607.4shall be increased 100 percent, but the area of light-transmitting plastic wall panels shall not exceed 50 percent of the wall area in any story, or the area permitted by Section 705.8for unprotected openings, whichever is smaller. These installations shall be exempt from height limitations.

subsections.title: 2607.6Combinations of glazing and wall panels.
subsections.content: Combinations of light-transmitting plastic glazing and light-transmitting plastic wall panels shall be subject to the area, height and percentage limitations and the separation requirements applicable to the class of light-transmitting plastic as prescribed for light-transmitting plastic wall panel installations.

subsections.title: 2608.1Buildings of Type VB construction.
subsections.content: Openings in theexterior wallsof buildings of Type VB construction, where not required to be protected by Section 705, shall be permitted to be glazed or equipped with light-transmitting plastic. Light-transmitting plastic glazing shall comply with Section 2606.

subsections.title: 2608.2Buildings of other types of construction.
subsections.content: Openings in theexterior wallsof buildings of types of construction other than Type VB, where not required to be protected by Section 705, shall be permitted to be glazed or equipped with light-transmitting plastic in accordance with Section 2606and all of the following:

sections.section: SECTION BC 2609 LIGHT-TRANSMITTING PLASTIC ROOF PANELS

subsections.title: 2609.1General.
subsections.content: Light-transmitting plastic roof panels shall comply with this section and Section 2606. Light-transmitting plastic roof panels shall not be installed in Groups H, I-2 and I-3. In all other groups, light-transmitting plastic roof panels shall comply with any one of the following conditions:

subsections.title: 2609.2Separation.
subsections.content: Individual roof panels shall be separated from each other by a distance of not less than 4 feet (1219 mm) measured in a horizontal plane.

subsections.title: 2609.3Location.
subsections.content: Whereexterior wallopenings are required to be protected by Section 705.8, a roof panel shall not be installed within 6 feet (1829 mm) of suchexterior wall.

subsections.title: 2609.4Area limitations.
subsections.content: Roof panels shall be limited in area and the aggregate area of panels shall be limited by a percentage of the floor area of the room or space sheltered in accordance with Table 2609.4.

subsections.title: 2610.1Light-transmitting plastic glazing of skylight assemblies.
subsections.content: Skylight assemblies glazed with light-transmitting plastic shall conform to the provisions of this section and Section 2606. Unit skylights glazed with light-transmitting plastic shall comply with Section 2405.5.

subsections.title: 2610.2Mounting.
subsections.content: The light-transmitting plastic shall be mounted above the plane of the roof on a curb constructed in accordance with the requirements for the type of construction classification, but not less than 4 inches (102 mm) above the plane of the roof. Edges of the light-transmitting plastic skylights or domes shall be protected by metal or other approved noncombustible material, or the light transmitting plastic dome or skylight shall be shown to be able to resist ignition where exposed at the edge to a flame from a Class B brand as described in ASTM E108or UL 790. The Class B brand test shall be conducted on a skylight that is elevated to a height as specified in the manufacturer’s installation instructions, but not less than 4 inches (102 mm).

subsections.title: 2610.3Slope.
subsections.content: Flat or corrugated light-transmitting plastic skylights shall slope not less than four units vertical in 12 units horizontal (4:12). Dome-shaped skylights shall rise above the mounting flange a minimum distance equal to 10 percent of the maximum width of the dome but not less than 3 inches (76 mm).

subsections.title: 2610.4Maximum area of skylights.
subsections.content: Each skylight shall have a maximum area within the curb of 100 square feet (9.3 m2).

subsections.title: 2610.5Aggregate area of skylights.
subsections.content: The aggregate area of skylights shall not exceed 331/3percent of the floor area of the room or space sheltered by the roof in which such skylights are installed where Class CC1 materials are utilized, and 25 percent where Class CC2 materials are utilized.

subsections.title: 2610.6Separation.
subsections.content: Skylights shall be separated from each other by a distance of not less than 4 feet (1219 mm) measured in a horizontal plane.

subsections.title: 2610.7Location.
subsections.content: Whereexterior wallopenings are required to be protected in accordance with Section 705, a skylight shall not be installed within 6 feet (1829 mm) of suchexterior wall.

subsections.title: 2610.8Combinations of roof panels and skylights.
subsections.content: Combinations of light-transmitting plastic roof panels and skylights shall be subject to the area and percentage limitations and separation requirements applicable to roof panel installations.

sections.section: SECTION BC 2611 LIGHT-TRANSMITTING PLASTIC INTERIOR SIGNS

subsections.title: 2611.1General.
subsections.content: Light-transmitting plastic interior signs shall be limited as specified in Sections 2606and 2611.2through 2611.4.

subsections.title: 2611.2Maximum area.
subsections.content: The aggregate area of all light-transmitting plastics shall not exceed 24 square feet (2.23 m2).

subsections.title: 2611.3Separation.
subsections.content: Signs exceeding the aggregate area of Section 2611.2shall be separated from each other by not less than 4 feet (1219 mm) horizontally and 8 feet (2438 mm) vertically.

subsections.title: 2611.4Encasement.
subsections.content: Backs of wall-mounted signs and non-illuminated portions of all signs regulated by this section shall be fully encased in metal.

subsections.title: 2612.1General.
subsections.content: Plastic composites shall consist of either wood/plastic composites or plastic lumber. Plastic composites shall comply with the provisions of this code and with the additional requirements of Section 2612.

subsections.title: 2612.2Labeling.
subsections.content: Plastic composite deck boards and stair treads, or their packaging, shall bear alabelthat indicates compliance with ASTM D7032and includes the allowable load and maximum allowable span determined in accordance with ASTM D7032. Plastic composite handrails and guards, or their packaging, shall bear a label that indicates compliance with ASTM D7032and includes the maximum allowable span determined in accordance with ASTM D7032.

subsections.title: 2612.3Flame spread index.
subsections.content: Plastic composite deck boards, stair treads, handrails and guards shall exhibit a flame spreadindex not exceeding 200 when tested in accordance with ASTM E84or UL 723with the test specimen remaining in place during the test.

subsections.title: 2612.4Termite and decay resistance.
subsections.content: Where required by Section 2304.12, plastic composite deck boards, stair treads, handrails and guards containing wood, cellulosic or any otherbiodegradable materials shall be termite and decay resistant as determined in accordance with ASTM D7032.

subsections.title: 2612.5Construction requirements.
subsections.content: Plastic composites meeting the requirements of Section 2612shall be permitted to be used as exterior deck boards, stair treads, handrails and guards where combustible construction is permitted.

subsubsections.title: 2612.5.1Span rating.
subsubsections.content: Plastic composites used as exterior deck boards shall have a span rating determined in accordance with ASTM D7032.

subsections.title: 2612.6Plastic composite deck boards, stair treads, handrails and guards.
subsections.content: Plastic composite deck boards, stair treads,handrails and guards shall be installed in accordance with this code and the manufacturer’s instructions.

subsections.title: 2613.1General.
subsections.content: The provisions of this section shall govern the requirements and uses offiber-reinforced polymerin and on buildings and structures.

subsections.title: 2613.2Labeling and identification.
subsections.content: Packages and containers offiber-reinforced polymerand their components delivered to the job site shall bear thelabelof anapproved agencyshowing the manufacturer’s name, product listing, product identification and information sufficient to determine that the end use will comply with the code requirements.

subsections.title: 2613.3Interior finishes.
subsections.content: Fiber-reinforced polymerused asinterior finishes, decorative materialsortrimshall comply with Chapter 8.

subsubsections.title: 2613.3.1Foam plastic cores.
subsubsections.content: Fiber-reinforced polymerused as interior finish and that contains foam plastic cores shall comply with Chapter 8and this chapter.

subsections.title: 2613.4Light-transmitting materials.
subsections.content: Fiber-reinforced polymerused as light-transmitting materials shall comply with Sections 2606through 2611as required for the specific application.

subsections.title: 2613.5Exterior use.
subsections.content: Fiber-reinforced polymershall be permitted to be installed on theexterior wallsof buildings of any type of construction where such polymers meet the requirements of Section 2603.5. Fireblocking shall be installed in accordance with Section 718.

sections.section: SECTION BC 2614 REFLECTIVE PLASTIC CORE INSULATION

subsections.title: 2614.1General.
subsections.content: The provisions of this section shall govern the requirements and uses of reflective plastic core insulation in buildings and structures. Reflective plastic core insulation shall comply with the requirements of Section 2614and of Section 2614.3or 2614.4.

subsections.title: 2614.2Identification.
subsections.content: Packages and containers of reflective plastic core insulation delivered to the job site shall show the manufacturer’s or supplier’s name, product identification and information sufficient to determine that the end use will comply with the code requirements.

subsections.title: 2614.3Surface-burning characteristics.
subsections.content: Reflective plastic core insulation shall have a flame spread index of not more than 25 and a smoke-developed index of not more than 450 when tested in accordance with ASTM E84or UL 723. The reflective plastic core insulation shall be tested at the maximum thickness intended for use. Test specimen preparation and mounting shall be in accordance with ASTM E2599.

subsections.title: 2614.4Room corner test heat release.
subsections.content: Reflective plastic core insulation shall comply with the acceptance criteria of Section 803.1.1.1when tested in accordance with NFPA 286or UL 1715in the manner intended for use and at the maximum thickness intended for use.

subsections.title: 2701.1Scope.
subsections.content: The provisions of this chapter and NFPA 70shall govern the design, construction, erection and installation of the electrical components, appliances, equipment and systems used in buildings and structures covered by this code. TheFire Code of New York State, theProperty Maintenance Code of New York Stateand NFPA 70shall govern the use and maintenance of electrical components, appliances, equipment and systems. TheExisting Building Code of New York Stateand NFPA 70shall govern the alteration, repair, relocation, replacement and addition of electrical components, appliances, or equipment and systems.

sections.section: SECTION BC 2702 EMERGENCY AND STANDBY POWER SYSTEMS

subsections.title: [F]2702.1General.
subsections.content: Emergency power systems and standby power systems shall comply with Sections 2702.1.1through 2702.1.8.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.1.1Stationary generators.
subsubsections.content: Stationary emergency and standby power generators required by this code shall be listed in accordance with UL 2200.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.1.2Fuel-line piping protection.
subsubsections.content: Fuel lines supplying a generator set inside ahigh-rise buildingshall be separated from areas of thebuildingother than the room the generator is located in by anapprovedmethod, or an assembly that has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 2 hours. Where thebuildingis protected throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, the required fire-resistance rating shall be reduced to 1 hour.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.1.3Installation.
subsubsections.content: Emergency power systems and standby power systems required by this code or theFire Code of New York Stateshall be installed in accordance with theFire Code of New York State, NFPA 70, NFPA 110and NFPA 111.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.1.4Load transfer.
subsubsections.content: Emergency power systems shall automatically provide secondary power within 10 seconds after primary power is lost, unless specified otherwise in this code. Standby power systems shall automatically provide secondary power within 60 seconds after primary power is lost, unless specified otherwise in this code.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.1.5Load duration.
subsubsections.content: Emergency power systems and standby power systems shall be designed to provide the required power for a minimum duration of 2 hours without being refueled or recharged, unless specified otherwise in this code.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.1.6Uninterruptable power source.
subsubsections.content: An uninterrupted source of power shall be provided for equipment where required by the manufacturer’s instructions, the listing, this code or applicable referenced standards.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.1.7Interchangeability.
subsubsections.content: Emergency power systems shall be an acceptable alternative for installations that require standby power systems.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.1.8Group I-2 occupancies.
subsubsections.content: In Group I-2occupancies located in flood hazard areas established in Section 1612.3, where new essential electrical systems are installed, and where new essential electrical system generators are installed, the systems and generators shall be located and installed in accordance withASCE24. Where connections for hookup of temporary generators are provided, the connections shall be located at or above the elevation required inASCE24.

subsections.title: [F]2702.2Where required.
subsections.content: Emergency and standby power systems shall be provided where required bySections 2702.2.1through 2702.2.18.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.1Ambulatory care facilities.
subsubsections.content: Essential electrical systems for ambulatory care facilities shall comply with Section 422.6.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.2Elevators and platform lifts.
subsubsections.content: Standby power shall be provided for elevators and platform lifts as required in Sections 1009.4.1, 1009.5, 3003.1, 3007.8and 3008.8.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.3Emergency responder radio coverage systems.
subsubsections.content: Standby power shall be provided for emergency responder radio coverage systems required in Section 918and theFire Code of New York State. The standby power supply shall be capable of operating the emergencyresponder radio coverage system for a duration of not less than 12 hours at 100-percent system operation capacity.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.4Emergency voice/alarm communication systems.
subsubsections.content: Emergency power shall be provided for emergency voice/alarm communication systems as required in Section 907.5.2.2.5. The system shall be capable of powering the required load for a duration of not less than 24 hours, as required in NFPA 72.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.5Exhaust systems.
subsubsections.content: Standby power shall be provided for common exhaust systems for domestic kitchens located in multistory structures as required in Section 505.5of theMechanical Code of New York State. Standby power shall be provided for common exhaust systems for clothes dryers located in multistory structures as required in Section 504.10of theMechanical Code of New York Stateand Section 614.10of theFuel Gas Code of New York State.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.6Exit signs.
subsubsections.content: Emergency power shall be provided for exit signs as required in Section 1013.6.3. The system shall be capable of powering the required load for a duration of not less than 90 minutes.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.7Gas detection system.
subsubsections.content: Emergency or standby power shall be provided for gas detection systems in accordance with theFire Code of New York State.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.8Group I-2 occupancies.
subsubsections.content: Essential electrical systems for Group I-2 occupancies shall be in accordance with Section 407.11.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.9Group I-3 occupancies.
subsubsections.content: Emergency power shall be provided for power-operated doors and locks in Group I-3 occupancies as required in Section 408.4.2.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.10Hazardous materials.
subsubsections.content: Emergency or standby power shall be provided in occupancies with hazardous materials where required by theFire Code of New York State.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.11High-rise buildings.
subsubsections.content: Emergency and standby power shall be provided in high-rise buildings as required in Section 403.4.8.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.12Laboratory suites.
subsubsections.content: Standby or emergency power shall be provided in accordance with Section 5004.7of theFire Code of New York Statewherelaboratory suitesare located above the sixth story above grade plane or located in a story below grade plane.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.13Means of egress illumination.
subsubsections.content: Emergency power shall be provided for means of egress illumination as required in Section 1008.3. The system shall be capable of powering the required load for a duration of not less than 90 minutes.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.14Membrane structures.
subsubsections.content: Standby power shall be provided for auxiliary inflation systems in permanent membrane structures as required in Section 3102.8.2. Standby power shall be provided for a duration of not less than 4 hours. Auxiliary inflation systems in temporary air-supported and air-inflated membrane structures shall be provided in accordance with Section 3103.10.4of theFire Code of New York State.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.15Semiconductor fabrication facilities.
subsubsections.content: Emergency power shall be provided for semiconductor fabrication facilities as required in Section 415.11.10.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.16Smoke control systems.
subsubsections.content: Standby power shall be provided for smoke control systems as required in Sections 404.7, 909.11, 909.20.6.2and 909.21.5.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.17Special purpose horizontal sliding, accordion or folding doors.
subsubsections.content: Standby power shall be provided for special purpose horizontal sliding, accordion or foldingdoors as required in Section 1010.1.4.3. The standby power supply shall have a capacity to operate not fewer than 50 closing cycles of the door.

subsubsections.title: [F]2702.2.18Underground buildings.
subsubsections.content: Emergency and standby power shall be provided in underground buildings as required in Section 405.

subsubsections.title: [NY]2702.2.19Exhaust ventilation systems.
subsubsections.content: Standby power shall be provided for mechanical exhaust ventilation systems in accordance with theFire Code of New York State.

subsections.title: [F]2702.3Critical circuits.
subsections.content: Required critical circuits shall be protected using one of the following methods:

subsections.title: [F]2702.4Maintenance.
subsections.content: Emergency and standby power systems shall be maintained and tested in accordance with theFire Code of New York State.

subsections.title: [M]2801.1Scope.
subsections.content: The provisions of this chapter, theMechanical Code of New York Stateand theFuel Gas Code of New York Stateshall govern the design, construction, erection and installation of mechanical appliances, equipment and systems used in buildings and structures covered by this code. Masonry chimneys, fireplaces and barbecues shall comply with theMechanical Code of New York Stateand Chapter 21of this code. TheFire Code of New York State, theProperty Maintenance Code of New York State, theMechanical Code of New York Stateand theFuel Gas Code of New York Stateshall govern the use and maintenance of mechanical components, appliances, equipment and systems. TheExisting Building Code of New York State, theMechanical Code of New York Stateand theFuel Gas Code of New York Stateshall govern the alteration, repair, relocation, replacement and addition of mechanical components, appliances, equipment and systems.

subsections.title: [NY]2901.1Scope.
subsections.content: The provisions of this chapter and thePlumbing Code of New York Stateshall govern the design, construction, erection and installation of plumbing components, appliances, equipment and systems used inbuildingsand structures covered by this code. Toilet and bathing rooms shall be constructed in accordance with Section 1209. TheFire Code of New York State, theProperty Maintenance Code of New York Stateand thePlumbing Code of New York Stateshall govern the use and maintenance of plumbing components, appliances, equipment and systems. TheExisting Building Code of New York Stateand thePlumbing Code of New York Stateshall govern thealteration,repair, relocation, replacement andadditionof plumbing components,appliances,equipmentand systems.

subsections.title: [P]2902.1Minimum number of fixtures.
subsections.content: Plumbing fixtures shall be provided in the minimum number as shown in Table 2902.1based on the actual use of the building or space. Uses not shown in Table 2902.1shall be considered individually by thebuilding official. The number of occupants shall be determined by this code.

subsubsections.title: [NY]2902.1.1Fixture calculations.
subsubsections.content: To determine the occupant load of each sex, the total occupant load shall be divided in half. To determine the required number of fixtures for each sex, the fixture ratio or ratios for each fixture type shall be applied to the occupant load of that sex in accordance with Table 2902.1. Fractional numbers resulting from applying the fixture ratios of Table 2902.1shall be rounded up to the next whole number.

subsubsections.title: [NY]2902.1.2Single-user toilet and bathing facilities.
subsubsections.content: Single-user toilet and bathing rooms, and family or assisted-use toilet rooms and bathing rooms shall be identified as being available for use by all persons regardless of their sex.

subsubsections.title: [NY]2902.1.3Multi-user toilet and bathing facilities.
subsubsections.content: Where multi-user facilities designed to serve all genders are provided, urinals shall be either located in stalls, or located in an area visually separated from the remainder of the facility. Privacy for water closets shall be installed in accordance with Section 1209.3.1.

subsubsections.title: [NY]2902.1.4Lavatory distribution.
subsubsections.content: Where two or more toilet rooms are provided for each sex, the required number of lavatories shall be distributed proportionately to the required number of water closets

subsections.title: [NY]2902.2Separate facilities.
subsections.content: Where plumbing fixtures are required, separate facilities shall be provided for each sex.

subsubsections.title: [P]2902.2.1Family or assisted-use toilet facilities serving as separate facilities.
subsubsections.content: Where a building or tenant space requires a separate toilet facility for each sex and each toilet facility is required to have only one water closet, two family or assisted-use toilet facilities shall be permitted to serve as the required separate facilities. Family or assisted-use toilet facilities shall not be required to be identified for exclusive use by either sex as required by Section 2902.4.

subsections.title: [P]2902.3Employee and public toilet facilities.
subsections.content: For structures and tenant spaces intended for public utilization, customers, patrons and visitors shall be provided with public toilet facilities. Employees associated with structures and tenant spaces shall be provided with toilet facilities. The number of plumbing fixtures located within the required toilet facilities shall be provided in accordance with Section 2902for all users. Employee toilet facilities shall be either separate or combined employee and public toilet facilities.

subsubsections.title: [P]2902.3.1Access.
subsubsections.content: The route to the public toilet facilities required by Section 2902.3shall not pass through kitchens, storage rooms or closets. Access to the required facilities shall be from within the building or from the exterior of the building. Routes shall comply with the accessibility requirements of this code. The public shall have access to the required toilet facilities at all times that the building is occupied.

subsubsections.title: [P]2902.3.2Prohibited toilet room location.
subsubsections.content: Toilet rooms shall not open directly into a room used for the preparation of food for service to the public.

subsubsections.title: [P]2902.3.3Location of toilet facilities in occupancies other than malls.
subsubsections.content: In occupancies other than covered and open mall buildings, the required public and employee toilet facilities shall be located not more than onestoryabove or below the space required to be provided with toilet facilities, and the path of travel to such facilities shall not exceed a distance of 500 feet (152 m).

subsubsections.title: [P]2902.3.4Location of toilet facilities in malls.
subsubsections.content: In covered and open mall buildings, the required public and employee toilet facilities shall be located not more than one story above or below the space required to be provided with toilet facilities, and the path of travel to such facilities shall not exceed a distance of 300 feet (91 mm). In mall buildings, the required facilities shall be based on total square footage (m2) within a covered mall building or within the perimeter line of an open mall building, and facilities shall be installed in each individual store or in a central toilet area located in accordance with this section. The maximum distance of travel to central toilet facilities in mall buildings shall be measured from the main entrance of any store or tenant space. In mall buildings, where employees’ toilet facilities are not provided in the individual store, the maximum distance of travel shall be measured from the employees’ work area of the store or tenant space.

subsubsections.title: [P]2902.3.5Pay facilities.
subsubsections.content: Where pay facilities are installed, such facilities shall be in excess of the required minimum facilities. Required facilities shall be free of charge.

subsubsections.title: [P]2902.3.6Door locking.
subsubsections.content: Where a toilet room is provided for the use of multiple occupants, the egress door for the room shall not be lockable from the inside of the room. This section does not apply to family or assisted-use toilet rooms.

subsections.title: [NY]2902.4Signage.
subsections.content: Required public facilities shall be provided with signs that designate the sex, as required by Section 2902.2. Signs shall be readily visible and located near the entrance to each toilet facility. Signs for accessible toilet facilities shall comply with Section 1111.

subsubsections.title: [P]2902.4.1Directional signage.
subsubsections.content: Directional signage indicating the route to the required public toilet facilities shall be posted in a lobby, corridor, aisle or similar space, such that the sign can be readily seen from the main entrance to the building or tenant space.

subsections.title: [P]2902.5Drinking fountain location.
subsections.content: Drinking fountains shall not be required to be located in individual tenant spaces provided that public drinking fountains are located within a distance of travel of 500 feet (152 m) of the most remote location in the tenant space and not more than one story above or below the tenant space. Where the tenant space is in a covered or open mall, such distance shall not exceed 300 feet (91 440 mm). Drinking fountains shall be located on an accessible route.

subsections.title: [P]2902.6Small occupancies.
subsections.content: Drinking fountains shall not be required for an occupant load of 15 or fewer.

subsections.title: [NY]2902.7Buildings required to provide alternative potable water access.
subsections.content: Buildings five or more stories in height that supply potable water from a public water main with the assistance of pumps todwelling unitsor sleeping units in Groups I-1, I-2, R-1, R-2, and R-4 occupancies shall provide emergency water fixtures. These fixtures shall, in an emergency when such pumps are inoperable, supply potable water from the public water main to the building using only the available pressure in the public water main. Such fixtures shall comply with Sections 2902.7.1through 2902.7.4.

subsubsections.title: [NY]2902.7.1Emergency water fixture.
subsubsections.content: Fixtures capable of supplying an emergency source of potable water in accordance with this section shall consist of either a faucet or a fixture suitable for supplying drinking water for human ingestion conforming to Sections 424.1and 424.1.1 of thePlumbing Code of New York State. Waste fittings shall comply with Section 424.1.2 of thePlumbing Code of New York State. Fixtures shall discharge to one of the following:

subsubsections.title: [NY]2902.7.2Number of emergency water fixtures required.
subsubsections.content: One such fixture shall be provided for each 100 occupants as determined by the occupant load of the building.

subsubsections.title: [NY]2902.7.3Access to emergency water fixtures.
subsubsections.content: Fixtures capable of supplying an emergency source of potable water in accordance with this section shall comply with all of the following:

subsubsections.title: [NY]2902.7.4Signage.
subsubsections.content: Fixtures capable of supplying an emergency source of potable water in accordance with this section shall be identified by a legible sign stating: “EMERGENCY DRINKING WATER.” Signs shall be readily visible and located near such fixtures and on the door to any room or closet in which such a fixture is located.

subsections.title: 301.1General.
subsections.content: The provisions of this chapter shall control the classification of all buildings and structures as to occupancy and use. Different classifications of occupancy and use represent varying levels of hazard and risk to building occupants and adjacent properties.

subsections.title: 302.1Occupancy classification.
subsections.content: Occupancy classification is the formal designation of the primary purpose of the building, structure or portion thereof. Structures shall be classified into one or more of the occupancy groups listed in this section based on the nature of the hazards and risks to building occupants generally associated with the intended purpose of the building or structure. An area, room or space that is intended to be occupied at different times for different purposes shall comply with all applicable requirements associated with such potential multipurpose. Structures containing multiple occupancy groups shall comply with Section 508. Where a structure is proposed for a purpose that is not specifically listed in this section, such structure shall be classified in the occupancy it most nearly resembles based on the fire safety and relative hazard. Occupied roofs shall be classified in the group that the occupancy most nearly resembles, according to the fire safety and relative hazard, and shall comply with Section 503.1.4.

subsections.title: 302.2Use designation.
subsections.content: Occupancy groups contain subordinate uses having similar hazards and risks to building occupants. Uses include, but are not limited to, those functional designations listed within the occupancy group descriptions in Section 302.1. Certain uses require specific limitations and controls in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 4and elsewhere in this code.

subsections.title: 303.1Assembly Group A.
subsections.content: Assembly Group A occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for the gathering of persons for purposes such as civic, social or religious functions; recreation, food or drink consumption or awaiting transportation.

subsubsections.title: 303.1.1Small buildings and tenant spaces.
subsubsections.content: A building or tenant space used for assembly purposes with anoccupant loadof less than 50 persons shall be classified as a Group B occupancy.

subsubsections.title: 303.1.2Small assembly spaces.
subsubsections.content: The following rooms and spaces shall not be classified as Assembly occupancies:

subsubsections.title: 303.1.3Associated with Group E occupancies.
subsubsections.content: A room or space used for assembly purposes that is associated with a Group E occupancy is not considered a separate occupancy.

subsubsections.title: 303.1.4Accessory to places of religious worship.
subsubsections.content: Accessory religious educational rooms and religious auditoriums withoccupant loadsof less than 100 per room or space are not considered separate occupancies.

subsections.title: 303.2Assembly Group A-1.
subsections.content: Group A-1 occupancy includes assembly uses, usually with fixed seating, intended for the production and viewing of the performing arts or motion pictures including, but not limited to:

subsections.title: 303.3Assembly Group A-2.
subsections.content: Group A-2 occupancy includes assembly uses intended for food and/or drink consumption including, but not limited to:

subsections.title: 303.4Assembly Group A-3.
subsections.content: Group A-3 occupancy includes assembly uses intended for worship, recreation or amusement and other assembly uses not classified elsewhere in Group A including, but not limited to:

subsections.title: 303.5Assembly Group A-4.
subsections.content: Group A-4 occupancy includes assembly uses intended for viewing of indoor sporting events and activities with spectator seating including, but not limited to:

subsections.title: 303.6Assembly Group A-5.
subsections.content: Group A-5 occupancy includes assembly uses intended for participation in or viewing outdoor activities including, but not limited to:

subsections.title: 304.1Business Group B.
subsections.content: Business Group B occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for office, professional or service-type transactions, including storage of records and accounts. Business occupancies shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsections.title: 305.1Educational Group E.
subsections.content: Educational Group E occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, by six or more persons at any one time for educational purposes through the 12th grade.

subsubsections.title: 305.1.1Accessory to places of religious worship.
subsubsections.content: Religious educational rooms and religious auditoriums, which are accessory toplaces of religious worshipin accordance with Section 303.1.4and haveoccupant loadsof less than 100 per room or space, shall be classified as Group A-3 occupancies.

subsections.title: 305.2Group E, day care facilities.
subsections.content: This group includes buildings and structures or portions thereof occupied by more than five children older than 21/2years of age who receive educational, supervision orpersonal care servicesfor fewer than 24 hours per day.

subsubsections.title: 305.2.1Within places of religious worship.
subsubsections.content: Rooms and spaces withinplaces of religious worshipproviding such day care during religious functions shall be classified as part of the primary occupancy.

subsubsections.title: 305.2.2Five or fewer children.
subsubsections.content: A facility having five or fewer children receiving such day care shall be classified as part of the primary occupancy.

subsubsections.title: 305.2.3Five or fewer children in a dwelling unit.
subsubsections.content: A facility such as the above within adwelling unitand having five or fewer children receiving such day care shall be classified as a Group R-3 occupancy or shall comply with theResidential Code of New York State.

subsections.title: 306.1Factory Industrial Group F.
subsections.content: Factory Industrial Group F occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for assembling, disassembling, fabricating, finishing, manufacturing, packaging, repair or processing operations that are not classified as a Group H hazardous or Group S storage occupancy.

subsections.title: 306.2Moderate-hazard factory industrial, Group F-1.
subsections.content: Factory industrial uses that are not classified as Factory Industrial F-2 Low Hazard shall be classified as F-1 Moderate Hazard and shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsections.title: 306.3Low-hazard factory industrial, Group F-2.
subsections.content: Factory industrial uses that involve the fabrication or manufacturing of noncombustible materials that during finishing, packing or processing do not involve a significant fire hazard shall be classified as F-2 occupancies and shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsections.title: [F]307.1High-hazard Group H.
subsections.content: High-hazard Group H occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, that involves the manufacturing, processing, generation or storage of materials that constitute a physical or health hazard in quantities in excess of those allowed incontrol areascomplying with Section 414, based on the maximum allowable quantity limits forcontrol areasset forth in Tables 307.1(1)and 307.1(2). Hazardous occupancies are classified in Groups H-1, H-2, H-3, H-4 and H-5 and shall be in accordance with this section, the requirements of Section 415and theFire Code of New York State. Hazardous materials stored, or used on top of roofs or canopies, shall be classified as outdoor storage or use and shall comply with theFire Code of New York State.

subsubsections.title: [F]307.1.1Uses other than Group H.
subsubsections.content: An occupancy that stores, uses or handles hazardous materials as described in one or more of the following items shall not be classified as Group H, but shall be classified as the occupancy that it most nearly resembles.

subsections.title: [F]307.2Hazardous materials.
subsections.content: Hazardous materials in any quantity shall conform to the requirements of this code, including Section 414, and theFire Code of New York State.

subsections.title: [F]307.3High-hazard Group H-1.
subsections.content: Buildings and structures containing materials that pose a detonation hazard shall be classified as Group H-1. Such materials shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsubsections.title: [F]307.3.1Occupancies containing explosives not classified as H-1.
subsubsections.content: The following occupancies containing explosive materials shall be classified as follows:

subsections.title: [F]307.4High-hazard Group H-2.
subsections.content: Buildings and structures containing materials that pose a deflagration hazard or a hazard from accelerated burning shall be classified as Group H-2. Such materials shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsections.title: [F]307.5High-hazard Group H-3.
subsections.content: Buildings and structures containing materials that readily support combustion or that pose a physical hazard shall be classified as Group H-3. Such materials shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsections.title: [F]307.6High-hazard Group H-4.
subsections.content: Buildings and structures containing materials that are health hazards shall be classified as Group H-4. Such materials shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsections.title: [F]307.7High-hazard Group H-5.
subsections.content: Semiconductor fabrication facilities and comparable research and development areas in which hazardous production materials (HPM) are used and the aggregate quantity of materials is in excess of those listed in Tables 307.1(1)and 307.1(2)shall be classified as Group H-5. Such facilities and areas shall be designed and constructed in accordance with Section 415.11.

subsections.title: [F]307.8Multiple hazards.
subsections.content: Buildings and structures containing a material or materials representing hazards that are classified in one or more of Groups H-1, H-2, H-3 and H-4 shall conform to the code requirements for each of the occupancies so classified.

subsections.title: 308.1Institutional Group I.
subsections.content: Institutional Group I occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, in which care or supervision is provided to persons who are or are not capable of self-preservation without physical assistance or in which persons are detained for penal or correctional purposes or in which the liberty of the occupants is restricted. Institutional occupancies shall be classified as Group I-1, I-2, I-3 or I-4.

subsections.title: 308.2Institutional Group I-1.
subsections.content: Institutional Group I-1 occupancy shall include buildings, structures or portions thereof for more than 16 persons, excluding staff, who reside on a 24-hour basis in a supervised environment and receive custodial care. Buildings of Group I-1 shall be classified as one of the occupancy conditions specified in Section 308.2.1or 308.2.2. This group shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsubsections.title: 308.2.1Condition 1.
subsubsections.content: This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which all persons receiving custodial care who, without any assistance, are capable of responding to an emergency situation to complete building evacuation.

subsubsections.title: 308.2.2Condition 2.
subsubsections.content: This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which there are any persons receiving custodial care who require limited verbal or physical assistance while responding to an emergency situation to complete building evacuation.

subsubsections.title: 308.2.3Six to 16 persons receiving custodial care.
subsubsections.content: A facility housing not fewer than six and not more than 16 persons receiving custodial care shall be classified as Group R-4.

subsubsections.title: 308.2.4Five or fewer persons receiving custodial care.
subsubsections.content: A facility with five or fewer persons receiving custodial care shall be classified as Group R-3 or shall comply with theResidential Code of New York Stateprovided anautomatic sprinkler systemis installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.3or Section P2904of theResidential Code of New York State.

subsections.title: 308.3Institutional Group I-2.
subsections.content: Institutional Group I-2 occupancy shall include buildings and structures used formedical careon a 24-hour basis for more than five persons who areincapable of self-preservation. This group shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsubsections.title: 308.3.1Occupancy conditions.
subsubsections.content: Buildings of Group I-2 shall be classified as one of the occupancy conditions specified in Section 308.3.1.1or 308.3.1.2.

subsubsections.title: 308.3.2Five or fewer persons receiving medical care.
subsubsections.content: A facility with five or fewer persons receiving medical care shall be classified as Group R-3 or shall comply with theResidential Code of New York Stateprovided anautomatic sprinkler systemis installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.3or Section P2904of theResidential Code of New York State.

subsections.title: 308.4Institutional Group I-3.
subsections.content: Institutional Group I-3 occupancy shall include buildings and structures that are inhabited by more than five persons who are under restraint or security. A Group I-3 facility is occupied by persons who are generallyincapable of self-preservationdue to security measures not under the occupants’ control. This group shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsubsections.title: 308.4.1Condition 1.
subsubsections.content: This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which free movement is allowed from sleeping areas, and other spaces where access or occupancy is permitted, to the exterior viameans of egresswithout restraint. A Condition 1 facility is permitted to be constructed as Group R.

subsubsections.title: 308.4.2Condition 2.
subsubsections.content: This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which free movement is allowed from sleeping areas and any other occupiedsmoke compartmentto one or more othersmoke compartments. Egress to the exterior is impeded by lockedexits.

subsubsections.title: 308.4.3Condition 3.
subsubsections.content: This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which free movement is allowed within individualsmoke compartments, such as within a residential unit comprised of individualsleeping unitsand group activity spaces, where egress is impeded by remotecontrolled release ofmeans of egressfrom such asmoke compartmentto anothersmoke compartment.

subsubsections.title: 308.4.4Condition 4.
subsubsections.content: This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which free movement is restricted from an occupied space. Remote-controlled release is provided to permit movement fromsleeping units, activity spaces and other occupied areas within thesmoke compartmentto othersmoke compartments.

subsubsections.title: 308.4.5Condition 5.
subsubsections.content: This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which free movement is restricted from an occupied space. Staff-controlled manual release is provided to permit movement fromsleeping units, activity spaces and other occupied areas within thesmoke compartmentto othersmoke compartments.

subsections.title: 308.5Institutional Group I-4, day care facilities.
subsections.content: Institutional Group I-4 occupancy shall include buildings and structures occupied by more than five persons of any age who receivecustodial carefor fewer than 24 hours per day by persons other than parents or guardians, relatives by blood, marriage or adoption, and in a place other than the home of the person cared for. This group shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsubsections.title: 308.5.1Classification as Group E.
subsubsections.content: A child day care facility that provides care for more than five but not more than 100 children 21/2years or less of age, where the rooms in which the children are cared for are located on alevel of exit dischargeserving such rooms and each of these child care rooms has anexitdoor directly to the exterior, shall be classified as Group E.

subsubsections.title: 308.5.2Within a place of religious worship.
subsubsections.content: Rooms and spaces withinplaces of religious worshipproviding such care during religious functions shall be classified as part of the primary occupancy.

subsubsections.title: 308.5.3Five or fewer persons receiving care.
subsubsections.content: A facility having five or fewer persons receivingcustodial careshall be classified as part of the primary occupancy.

subsubsections.title: 308.5.4Five or fewer persons receiving care in a dwelling unit.
subsubsections.content: A facility such as the above within adwelling unitand having five or fewer persons receivingcustodial careshall be classified as a Group R-3 occupancy or shall comply with theResidential Code of New York State.

subsections.title: 309.1Mercantile Group M.
subsections.content: Mercantile Group M occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure or a portion thereof for the display and sale of merchandise, and involves stocks of goods, wares or merchandise incidental to such purposes and accessible to the public. Mercantile occupancies shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsections.title: 309.2Quantity of hazardous materials.
subsections.content: The aggregate quantity of nonflammable solid and nonflammable or noncombustible liquid hazardous materials stored or displayed in a singlecontrol areaof a Group M occupancy shall not exceed the quantities in Table 414.2.5(1).

subsections.title: 310.1Residential Group R.
subsections.content: Residential Group R includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for sleeping purposes when not classified as an Institutional Group I or when not regulated by theResidential Code of New York State.

subsections.title: 310.2Residential Group R-1.
subsections.content: Residential Group R-1 occupancies containingsleeping unitswhere the occupants are primarilytransientin nature, including:

subsections.title: 310.3Residential Group R-2.
subsections.content: Residential Group R-2 occupancies containingsleeping unitsor more than twodwelling unitswhere the occupants are primarily permanent in nature, including:

subsections.title: 310.4Residential Group R-3.
subsections.content: Residential Group R-3 occupancies where the occupants are primarily permanent in nature and not classified as Group R-1, R-2, R-4 or I, including:

subsubsections.title: 310.4.1Care facilities within a dwelling.
subsubsections.content: Care facilities for five or fewer persons receiving care that are within a single-family dwelling are permitted to comply with theResidential Code of New York Stateprovided anautomatic sprinkler systemis installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.3or Section P2904of theResidential Code of New York State.

subsubsections.title: 310.4.2Lodging houses.
subsubsections.content: Owner-occupiedlodging houseswith five or fewerguest roomsand 10 or fewer total occupants shall be permitted to be constructed in accordance with theResidential Code of New York State.

subsections.title: 310.5Residential Group R-4.
subsections.content: Residential Group R-4 occupancy shall include buildings, structures or portions thereof for more than five but not more than 16 persons, excluding staff, who reside on a 24-hour basis in a supervised residential environment and receivecustodial care. Buildings of Group R-4 shall be classified as one of the occupancy conditions specified in Section 310.5.1or 310.5.2. This group shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsubsections.title: 310.5.1Condition 1.
subsubsections.content: This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which all persons receiving custodial care, without any assistance, are capable of responding to an emergency situation to complete building evacuation.

subsubsections.title: 310.5.2Condition 2.
subsubsections.content: This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which there are any persons receiving custodial care who require limited verbal or physical assistance while responding to an emergency situation to complete building evacuation.

subsections.title: 311.1Storage Group S.
subsections.content: Storage Group S occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for storage that is not classified as a hazardous occupancy.

subsubsections.title: 311.1.1Accessory storage spaces.
subsubsections.content: A room or space used for storage purposes that is accessory to another occupancy shall be classified as part of that occupancy.

subsections.title: 311.2Moderate-hazard storage, Group S-1.
subsections.content: Storage Group S-1 occupancies are buildings occupied for storage uses that are not classified as Group S-2, including, but not limited to, storage of the following:

subsections.title: 311.3Low-hazard storage, Group S-2.
subsections.content: Storage Group S-2 occupancies include, among others, buildings used for the storage of noncombustible materials such as products on wood pallets or in paper cartons with or without single thickness divisions; or in paper wrappings. Such products are permitted to have a negligible amount of plastictrim, such as knobs, handles or film wrapping. Group S-2 storage uses shall include, but not be limited to, storage of the following:

sections.section: SECTION BC 312 UTILITY AND MISCELLANEOUS GROUP U

subsections.title: [NY]312.1General.
subsections.content: Buildings and structures of an accessory character and miscellaneous structures not classified in any specific occupancy shall be constructed, equipped and maintained to conform to the requirements of this code commensurate with the fire and life hazard incidental to their occupancy. Group U shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

subsubsections.title: 312.1.1Greenhouses.
subsubsections.content: Greenhouses not classified as another occupancy shall be classified as Use Group U.

subsections.title: 3001.1Scope.
subsections.content: This chapter governs the design, construction, installation,alterationand repair of elevators and conveying systems and their components.

subsections.title: [NY]3001.2Emergency elevator communication systems for the deaf, hard of hearing and speech impaired.
subsections.content: An emergency two-way communication system shall be provided. The system shall provide visible text and audible modes that:

subsections.title: 3001.3Referenced standards.
subsections.content: Except as otherwise provided for in this code, the design, construction, installation,alteration, repair and maintenance of elevators andconveying systems and their components shall conform to the applicable standard specified in Table 3001.3andASCE24for construction in flood hazard areas established in Section 1612.3.

subsections.title: 3001.4Accessibility.
subsections.content: Passenger elevators required to be accessible or to serve as part of anaccessible means of egressshall comply with Sections 1009and 1109.7.

subsections.title: 3001.5Change in use.
subsections.content: A change in use of an elevator from freight to passenger, passenger to freight, or from one freight class to another freight class shall comply with Section 8.7 of ASME A17.1/CSA B44.

subsections.title: 3002.1Hoistway enclosure protection.
subsections.content: Elevator, dumbwaiter and other hoistway enclosures shall beshaft enclosurescomplying with Sections 712and 713.

subsubsections.title: 3002.1.1Opening protectives.
subsubsections.content: Openings in hoistway enclosures shall be protected as required in Chapter 7.

subsubsections.title: 3002.1.2Hardware.
subsubsections.content: Hardware on opening protectives shall be of anapprovedtype installed as tested, except thatapprovedinterlocks, mechanical locks and electric contacts, door and gate electric contacts and door-operating mechanisms shall be exempt from the fire test requirements.

subsections.title: 3002.2Number of elevator cars in a hoistway.
subsections.content: Where four or more elevator cars serve all or the same portion of a building, the elevators shall be located in not fewer than two separate hoistways. Not more than four elevator cars shall be located in any single hoistway enclosure.

subsections.title: 3002.3Emergency signs.
subsections.content: Anapprovedpictorial sign of a standardized design shall be posted adjacent to each elevator call station on all floors instructing occupants to use theexit stairwaysand not to use the elevators in case of fire. The sign shall read: IN CASE OF FIRE, ELEVATORS ARE OUT OF SERVICE. USE EXIT STAIRS.

subsections.title: 3002.4Elevator car to accommodate ambulance stretcher.
subsections.content: Where elevators are provided in buildings four or morestoriesabove, or four or morestoriesbelow,grade plane, not fewer than one elevator shall be provided for fire department emergency access to all floors. The elevator car shall be of such a size and arrangement to accommodate an ambulance stretcher 24 inches by 84 inches (610 mm by 2134 mm) with not less than 5-inch (127 mm) radius corners, in the horizontal, open position and shall be identified by the international symbol for emergency medical services (star of life). The symbol shall be not less than 3 inches (76 mm) in height and shall be placed inside on both sides of the hoistway door frame.

subsections.title: 3002.5Emergency doors.
subsections.content: Where an elevator is installed in a single blind hoistway or on the outside of a building, there shall be installed in the blind portion of the hoistway or blank face of the building, an emergency door in accordance with ASME A17.1/CSA B44.

subsections.title: 3002.6Prohibited doors.
subsections.content: Doors, other than hoistway doors and the elevator car door, shall be prohibited at the point of access to an elevator car unless such doors are readily openable from the car side without a key, tool, special knowledge or effort.

subsections.title: 3002.7Common enclosure with stairway.
subsections.content: Elevators shall not be in a commonshaft enclosurewith astairway.

subsections.title: 3002.8Glass in elevator enclosures.
subsections.content: Glass in elevator enclosures shall comply with Section 2409.2.

subsections.title: 3002.9Plumbing and mechanical systems.
subsections.content: Plumbing and mechanical systems shall not be located in an elevator hoistway enclosure.

subsections.title: [F]3003.1Standby power.
subsections.content: In buildings and structures where standby power is required or furnished to operate an elevator, the operation shall be in accordance with Sections 3003.1.1through 3003.1.4.

subsubsections.title: [F]3003.1.1Manual transfer.
subsubsections.content: Standby power shall be manually transferable to all elevators in each bank.

subsubsections.title: [F]3003.1.2One elevator.
subsubsections.content: Where only one elevator is installed, the elevator shall automatically transfer to standby power within 60 seconds after failure of normal power.

subsubsections.title: [F]3003.1.3Two or more elevators.
subsubsections.content: Where two or more elevators are controlled by a common operating system, all elevators shall automatically transfer to standby power within 60 seconds after failure of normal power where the standby power source is of sufficient capacity to operate all elevators at the same time. Where the standby power source is not of sufficient capacity to operate all elevators at the same time, all elevators shall transfer to standby power in sequence, return to the designated landing and disconnect from the standby power source. After all elevators have been returned to the designated level, not less than one elevator shall remain operable from the standby power source.

subsubsections.title: [F]3003.1.4Venting.
subsubsections.content: Where standby power is connected to elevators, the machine roomventilationor air conditioning shall be connected to the standby power source.

subsections.title: [F]3003.2Fire fighters’ emergency operation.
subsections.content: Elevators shall be provided with Phase I emergency recall operation and Phase II emergency in-car operation in accordance with ASME A17.1/CSA B44.

subsections.title: [F]3003.3Standardized fire service elevator keys.
subsections.content: All elevators shall be equipped to operate with a standardized fire service elevator key in accordance with theFire Code of New York State.

subsections.title: 3004.1General.
subsections.content: Escalators, moving walks, conveyors, personnel hoists and material hoists shall comply with the provisions of Sections 3004.2through 3004.4.

subsections.title: 3004.2Escalators and moving walks.
subsections.content: Escalators and moving walks shall be constructed ofapprovednoncombustible and fire-retardant materials. This requirement shall not apply to electrical equipment, wiring, wheels, handrails and the use of1/28-inch (0.9 mm) wood veneers on balustrades backed up with noncombustible materials.

subsubsections.title: 3004.2.1Enclosure.
subsubsections.content: Escalator floor openings shall be enclosed withshaft enclosurescomplying with Section 713.

subsubsections.title: 3004.2.2Escalators.
subsubsections.content: Where provided in below-grade transportation stations, escalators shall have a clear width of not less than 32 inches (815 mm).

subsections.title: 3004.3Conveyors.
subsections.content: Conveyors and conveying systems shall comply with ASME B20.1.

subsubsections.title: 3004.3.1Enclosure.
subsubsections.content: Conveyors and related equipment connecting successive floors or levels shall be enclosed withshaft enclosurescomplying with Section 713.

subsubsections.title: 3004.3.2Conveyor safeties.
subsubsections.content: Power-operated conveyors, belts and other material-moving devices shall be equipped with automatic limit switches that will shut off the power in an emergency and automatically stop all operation of the device.

subsections.title: 3004.4Personnel and material hoists.
subsections.content: Personnel and material hoists shall be designed utilizing anapprovedmethod that accounts for the conditions imposed during the intended operation of the hoist device. The design shall include, but is not limited to, anticipated loads, structural stability, impact, vibration, stresses and seismic restraint. The design shall account for the construction, installation, operation and inspection of the hoist tower, car, machinery and control equipment, guide members and hoisting mechanism. Additionally, the design of personnel hoists shall include provisions for field testing and maintenance that will demonstrate that the hoist device functions in accordance with the design. Field tests shall be conducted upon the completion of an installation or following a majoralterationof a personnel hoist.

subsections.title: 3005.1Access.
subsections.content: Anapprovedmeans of access shall be provided to elevator machine rooms, control rooms, control spaces and machinery spaces.

subsections.title: 3005.2Venting.
subsections.content: Elevator machine rooms, machinery spaces that contain the driving machine, and control rooms or spaces that contain the operation or motion controller for elevator operation shall be provided with an independentventilationor air-conditioning system to protect against the overheating of the electrical equipment. The system shall be capable of maintaining temperatures within the range established for the elevator equipment.

subsections.title: 3005.3Pressurization.
subsections.content: The elevator machine room, control rooms or control space with openings into a pressurized elevator hoistway shall be pressurized upon activation of aheat or smoke detectorlocated in the elevator machine room, control room or control space.

subsections.title: 3005.4Machine rooms, control rooms, machinery spaces, and control spaces.
subsections.content: Elevator machine rooms, control rooms, control spaces and machinery spaces outside of but attached to a hoistway that have openings into the hoistway shall be enclosed withfire barriersconstructed in accordance with Section 707orhorizontal assembliesconstructed in accordance with Section 711, or both. Thefire-resistance ratingshall be not less than the required rating of the hoistway enclosure served by the machinery. Openings in thefire barriersshall be protected with assemblies having afire protection ratingnot less than that required for the hoistway enclosure doors.

subsections.title: 3005.5Shunt trip.
subsections.content: Where elevator hoistways, elevator machine rooms, control rooms and control spaces containing elevator control equipment are protected with automatic sprinklers, a means installed in accordance with Section 21.4 of NFPA 72shall be provided to automatically disconnect the main line power supply to the affected elevator prior to the application of water. This means shall not be self-resetting. The activation of automatic sprinklers outside the hoistway, machine room, machinery space, control room or control space shall not disconnect the main line power supply.

subsections.title: 3005.6Plumbing systems.
subsections.content: Plumbing systems shall not be located in elevator equipment rooms.

sections.section: SECTION BC 3006 ELEVATOR LOBBIES ANDHOISTWAY OPENING PROTECTION

subsections.title: 3006.1General.
subsections.content: Elevator hoistway openings and enclosed elevator lobbies shall be provided in accordance with the following:

subsections.title: 3006.2Hoistway opening protection required.
subsections.content: Elevator hoistway door openings shall be protected in accordance with Section 3006.3where an elevator hoistway connects more than three stories, is required to be enclosed within a shaft enclosure in accordance with Section 712.1.1and any of the following conditions apply:

subsubsections.title: 3006.2.1Rated corridors.
subsubsections.content: Where corridors are required to be fire-resistance rated in accordance with Section 1020.1, elevator hoistway openings shall be protected in accordance with Section 3006.3.

subsections.title: 3006.3Hoistway opening protection.
