subsubsections.content: Concrete columns shall comply with this section.

subsections.title: 722.3Concrete masonry.
subsections.content: The provisions of this section contain procedures by which thefire-resistance ratingsof concrete masonry are established by calculations.

subsubsections.title: 722.3.1Equivalent thickness.
subsubsections.content: The equivalent thickness of concrete masonry construction shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of this section.

subsubsections.title: 722.3.2Concrete masonry walls.
subsubsections.content: Thefire-resistance ratingof walls and partitions constructed of concrete masonry units shall be determined from Table 722.3.2. The rating shall be based on the equivalent thickness of the masonry and type of aggregate used.

subsubsections.title: 722.3.3Multiwythe masonry walls.
subsubsections.content: Thefire-resistance ratingof wall assemblies constructed of multiple wythes of masonry materials shall be permitted to be based on thefire-resistance ratingperiod of each wythe and the continuous airspace between each wythe in accordance with the following formula:

subsubsections.title: 722.3.4Concrete masonry lintels.
subsubsections.content: Fire-resistance ratingsfor concrete masonry lintels shall be determined based on the nominal thickness of the lintel and the minimum thickness of concrete masonry or concrete, or any combination thereof, covering the main reinforcing bars, as determined in accordance with Table 722.3.4, or byapprovedalternate methods.

subsubsections.title: 722.3.5Concrete masonry columns.
subsubsections.content: Thefire-resistance ratingof concrete masonry columns shall be determined based on the least plan dimension of the column in accordance with Table 722.3.5or byapprovedalternate methods.

subsections.title: 722.4Clay brick and tile masonry.
subsections.content: The provisions of this section contain procedures by which thefire-resistance ratingsof clay brick and tile masonry are established by calculations.

subsubsections.title: 722.4.1Masonry walls.
subsubsections.content: Thefire-resistance ratingof masonry walls shall be based on the equivalent thickness as calculated in accordance with this section. The calculation shall take into account finishes applied to the wall and airspaces between wythes in multiwythe construction.

subsubsections.title: 722.4.2Multiwythe walls.
subsubsections.content: Thefire-resistance ratingfor walls or partitions consisting of two or more dissimilar wythes shall be permitted to be determined by the formula:

subsubsections.title: 722.4.3Reinforced clay masonry lintels.
subsubsections.content: Fire-resistance ratingsfor clay masonry lintels shall be determined based on the nominal width of the lintel and the minimum covering for the longitudinal reinforcement in accordance with Table 722.4.1(5).

subsubsections.title: 722.4.4Reinforced clay masonry columns.
subsubsections.content: Thefire-resistance ratingsshall be determined based on the last plan dimension of the column in accordance with Table 722.4.1(6). The minimum cover for longitudinal reinforcement shall be 2 inches (51 mm).

subsections.title: 722.5Steel assemblies.
subsections.content: The provisions of this section contain procedures by which thefire-resistance ratingsof steel assemblies are established by calculations.

subsubsections.title: 722.5.1Structural steel columns.
subsubsections.content: Thefire-resistance ratingsof structural steel columns shall be based on the size of the element and the type of protection provided in accordance with this section.

subsubsections.title: 722.5.2Structural steel beams and girders.
subsubsections.content: Thefire-resistance ratingsof structural steel beams and girders shall be based on the size of the element and the type of protection provided in accordance with this section.

subsections.title: 722.6Wood assemblies.
subsections.content: The provisions of this section contain procedures by which thefire-resistance ratingsof wood assemblies are established by calculations.

subsubsections.title: 722.6.1General.
subsubsections.content: This section contains procedures for calculating thefire-resistance ratingsof walls, floor/ceiling and roof/ceiling assemblies based in part on the standard method of testing referenced in Section 703.2.

subsubsections.title: 722.6.2Walls, floors and roofs.
subsubsections.content: These procedures apply to both load-bearing and nonload-bearing assemblies.

subsections.title: 801.1Scope.
subsections.content: The provisions of this chapter shall govern the use of materials used asinterior finishes,trimanddecorative materials.

subsections.title: 802.1Interior wall and ceiling finish.
subsections.content: The provisions of Section 803shall limit the allowable fire performance and smoke development ofinterior wall and ceiling finishmaterials based on occupancy classification.

subsections.title: 802.2Interior floor finish.
subsections.content: The provisions of Section 804shall limit the allowable fire performance ofinterior floor finishmaterials based on occupancy classification.

subsections.title: [F]802.3Decorative materials and trim.
subsections.content: Decorative materialsandtrimshall be restricted by combustibility, fire performance or flame propagation performance criteria in accordance with Section 806.

subsections.title: 802.4Applicability.
subsections.content: For buildings in flood hazard areas as established in Section 1612.3,interior finishes,trimanddecorative materialsbelow the elevation required by Section 1612shall be flood-damage-resistant materials.

subsections.title: 802.5Application.
subsections.content: Combustible materials shall be permitted to be used as finish for walls, ceilings, floors and other interior surfaces of buildings.

subsections.title: 802.6Windows.
subsections.content: Show windows in the exterior walls of the firststoryabove grade plane shall be permitted to be of wood or of unprotected metal framing.

subsections.title: 802.7Foam plastics.
subsections.content: Foam plastics shall not be used asinterior finishexcept as provided in Section 803.4. Foam plastics shall not be used as interiortrimexcept as provided in Section 806.5or 2604.2. This section shall apply both to exposed foam plastics and to foam plastics used in conjunction with a textile or vinyl facing or cover.

sections.section: SECTION BC 803 WALL AND CEILING FINISHES

subsections.title: 803.1General.
subsections.content: Interior wall and ceiling finishmaterials shall be classified for fire performance and smoke development in accordance with Section 803.1.1or 803.1.2, except as shown in Sections 803.1.3through 803.15. Materials tested in accordance with Section 803.1.1shall not be required to be tested in accordance with Section 803.1.2.

subsubsections.title: 803.1.1Interior wall and ceiling finish materials tested in accordance with NFPA 286.
subsubsections.content: Interior wall and ceiling finishmaterials shall be classified in accordance with NFPA 286and comply with Section 803.1.1.1. Materials complying with Section 803.1.1.1shall be considered to also comply with the requirements of Class A.

subsubsections.title: 803.1.2Interior wall and ceiling finish materials tested in accordance with ASTM E84or UL 723.
subsubsections.content: Interior wallandceiling finishmaterials shall be classified in accordance with ASTM E84or UL 723. Suchinterior finishmaterials shall be grouped in the following classes in accordance with their flame spread andsmoke-developed indices.

subsubsections.title: 803.1.3Interior wall and ceiling finish materials with different requirements.
subsubsections.content: The materials indicated in Sections 803.2through 803.13shall be tested as indicated in the corresponding sections.

subsections.title: 803.2Thickness exemption.
subsections.content: Materials having a thickness less than 0.036 inch (0.9 mm) applied directly to the surface of walls or ceilings shall not be required to be tested.

subsections.title: 803.3Heavy timber exemption.
subsections.content: Exposed portions of building elements complying with the requirements for buildingsof heavy timber construction in Section 602.4or Section 2304.11shall not be subject tointerior finishrequirements except in interior exit stairways, interior exit ramps, and exit passageways.

subsections.title: 803.4Foam plastics.
subsections.content: Foam plastics shall not be used asinterior finishexcept as provided in Section 2603.9. This section shall apply both to exposed foam plastics and to foam plastics used in conjunction with a textile or vinyl facing or cover.

subsections.title: 803.5Textile wall coverings.
subsections.content: Where used as interior wall finish materials, textile wall coverings, including materials having woven or nonwoven, napped, tufted, looped or similar surface and carpet and similar textile materials, shall be tested in the manner intended for use, using the product-mounting system, including adhesive, and shall comply with therequirements of one of the following: Section 803.1.1, 803.5.1or 803.5.2.

subsubsections.title: 803.5.1Room corner test for textile wall coverings and expanded vinyl wall coverings.
subsubsections.content: Textile wall coverings andexpanded vinyl wall coveringsshall meet the criteria of Section 803.5.1.1when tested in the manner intended for use in accordance with the Method B protocol of NFPA 265using the product-mounting system, including adhesive.

subsubsections.title: 803.5.2Acceptance criteria for textile and expanded vinyl wall or ceiling coverings tested to ASTM E84or UL 723.
subsubsections.content: Textile wall and ceiling coverings and expanded vinyl wall and ceiling coverings shall have a Class Aflame spread indexin accordance with ASTM E84or UL 723and be protected by an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1or 903.3.1.2. Test specimen preparation and mounting shall be in accordance with ASTM E2404.

subsections.title: 803.6Textile ceiling coverings.
subsections.content: Where used as interior ceiling finish materials, textile ceiling coverings, including materials having woven or nonwoven, napped, tufted, looped or similar surface and carpet and similar textile materials, shall be tested in the manner intended for use, using the product-mounting system, including adhesive, and shall comply with the requirements of Section 803.1.1or 803.5.2.

subsections.title: 803.7Expanded vinyl wall coverings.
subsections.content: Where used as interior wall finish materials,expanded vinyl wall coveringsshall be tested in the manner intended for use, using the product-mounting system, including adhesive, and shall comply withthe requirements of one of the following: Section 803.1.1, 803.5.1or 803.5.2.

subsections.title: 803.8Expanded vinyl ceiling coverings.
subsections.content: Where used as interior ceiling finish materials, expanded vinyl ceiling coverings shall be tested in the manner intended for use, using the product mounting system, including adhesive, and shall comply with the requirements of Section 803.1.1or 803.5.2.

subsections.title: 803.9High-density polyethylene (HDPE) and polypropylene (PP).
subsections.content: Where high-density polyethylene or polypropylene is used as aninterior finish, it shall comply with Section 803.1.1.

subsections.title: 803.10Site-fabricated stretch systems.
subsections.content: Where used as interior wall or interior ceiling finish materials,site-fabricated stretch systemscontaining all three components described in the definition in Chapter 2shall be tested in the manner intended for use, and shall comply with the requirements of Section 803.1.1or 803.1.2. If the materials are tested in accordance with ASTM E84or UL 723, specimen preparation and mounting shall be in accordance with ASTM E2573.

subsections.title: 803.11Laminated products factory produced with a wood substrate.
subsections.content: Laminated products factory produced with a wood substrate shall comply with one of the following:

subsections.title: 803.12Facings or wood veneers intended to be applied on site over a wood substrate.
subsections.content: Facings or veneers intended to be applied on site over a wood substrate shall comply with one of the following:

subsections.title: 803.13Interior finish requirements based on occupancy.
subsections.content: Interior wall and ceiling finishshall have aflame spread indexnot greater than that specified in Table 803.13for the group and location designated.Interior wall and ceiling finishmaterials tested in accordance with NFPA 286and meeting the acceptance criteria of Section 803.1.1.1, shall be permitted to be used where a Class A classification in accordance with ASTM E84or UL 723is required.

subsections.title: 803.14Stability.
subsections.content: Interior finishmaterials regulated by this chapter shall be applied or otherwise fastened in such a manner that such materials will not readily become detached where subjected to room temperatures of 200°F (93°C) for not less than 30 minutes.

subsections.title: 803.15Application of interior finish materials to fire-resistance-rated or noncombustible building elements.
subsections.content: Whereinterior finishmaterials are applied on walls, ceilings or structural elements required to have afire-resistance ratingor to be of noncombustible construction, these finish materials shall comply with the provisions of this section.

subsubsections.title: 803.15.1Direct attachment and furred construction.
subsubsections.content: Where walls, ceilings or structural elements are requiredby any provision in this code to be of fire-resistance-rated or noncombustible construction, theinterior finishmaterial shall be applied directly against such construction or to furring strips not exceeding 13/4inches (44 mm), applied directly against such surfaces.

subsubsections.title: 803.15.2Set-out construction.
subsubsections.content: Where walls and ceilings are required to be of fire-resistance-rated or noncombustible construction and walls are set out or ceilings are dropped distances greater than specified in Section 803.15.1, Class A finish materials, in accordance with Section 803.1.1or 803.1.2, shall be used.

subsubsections.title: 803.15.3Heavy timber construction.
subsubsections.content: Wall and ceiling finishes of all classes as permitted in this chapter that are installed directly against the wood decking or planking ofheavy timber construction in Section 602.4.2or 2304.11or to wood furring strips applied directly to the wood decking or planking shall be fireblocked as specified in Section 803.15.1.1.

subsubsections.title: 803.15.4Materials.
subsubsections.content: An interior wall or ceiling finish material that is not more than1/4inch (6.4 mm) thick shall be applied directly onto the wall, ceiling or structural element without the use of furring strips and shall not be suspended away from the building element to which that finish material it is applied.

subsections.title: 804.1General.
subsections.content: Interior floor finishand floor covering materials shall comply with Sections 804.2through 804.4.2.

subsections.title: 804.2Classification.
subsections.content: Interior floor finishand floor covering materials required by Section 804.4.2to be of Class I or IImaterials shall be classified in accordance with ASTM E648or NFPA 253. The classification referred to herein corresponds to the classifications determined by ASTM E648orNFPA 253as follows: Class I, 0.45 watts/cm2or greater; Class II, 0.22 watts/cm2or greater.

subsections.title: 804.3Testing and identification.
subsections.content: Interior floor finishand floor covering materials shall be tested by an agency inaccordance with ASTM E648or NFPA 253and identified by ahang tag or other suitable method so as to identify the manufacturer or supplier and style, and shall indicate theinterior floor finishor floor covering classification in accordance with Section 804.2. Carpet-type floor coverings shall be tested as proposed for use, including underlayment. Test reports confirming the information provided in the manufacturer’s product identification shall be furnished to the building official upon request.

subsections.title: 804.4Interior floor finish requirements.
subsections.content: Interior floor covering materials shall comply with Sections 804.4.1and 804.4.2andinterior floor finishmaterials shall comply with Section 804.4.2.

subsubsections.title: 804.4.1Test requirement.
subsubsections.content: In all occupancies, interior floor covering materials shall comply with the requirements of the DOC FF-1 “pill test” (CPSC16 CFR Part 1630) or with ASTM D2859.

subsubsections.title: 804.4.2Minimum critical radiant flux.
subsubsections.content: In all occupancies,interior floor finishand floor covering materials in enclosures for stairways and ramps, exit passageways, corridors and rooms or spaces not separated from corridors by partitions extending from the floor to the underside of the ceiling shall withstand a minimum critical radiant flux. The minimum critical radiant flux shall be not less than Class I in Groups I-1, I-2 and I-3 and not less than Class II in Groups A, B, E, H, I-4, M, R-1, R-2 and S.

sections.section: SECTION BC 805 COMBUSTIBLE MATERIALS INTYPES I AND II CONSTRUCTION

subsections.title: 805.1Application.
subsections.content: Combustible materials installed on or embedded in floors of buildings of Type I or II construction shall comply with Sections 805.1.1through 805.1.3.

subsubsections.title: 805.1.1Subfloor construction.
subsubsections.content: Floor sleepers, bucks and nailing blocks shall not be constructed of combustible materials, unless the space between the fire-resistance-rated floor assembly and the flooring is either solidly filled with noncombustible materials or fireblocked in accordance with Section 718, and provided that such open spaces shall not extend under or through permanent partitions or walls.

subsubsections.title: 805.1.2Wood finish flooring.
subsubsections.content: Wood finish flooring is permitted to be attached directly to the embedded or fireblocked wood sleepers and shall be permitted where cemented directly to the top surface of fire-resistance-rated floor assemblies or directly to a wood subfloor attached to sleepers as provided for in Section 805.1.1.

subsubsections.title: 805.1.3Insulating boards.
subsubsections.content: Combustible insulating boards not more than1/2inch (12.7 mm) thick and covered with finish flooring are permitted where attached directly to a noncombustible floor assembly or to wood subflooring attached to sleepers as provided for in Section 805.1.1.

sections.section: SECTION BC 806 DECORATIVE MATERIALS AND TRIM

subsections.title: [F]806.1General.
subsections.content: The following requirements shall apply to all occupancies:

subsections.title: [F]806.2Combustible decorative materials.
subsections.content: In Groups A, B, E, I, M and R-1 and in dormitories in Group R-2, curtains, draperies, fabric hangings and similar combustible decorative materials suspended from walls or ceilings shall comply with Section 806.4and shall not exceed 10 percent of the specific wall or ceiling area to which such materials are attached.

subsections.title: 806.3Occupancy-based requirements.
subsections.content: Occupancy-based requirements for combustible decorative materials, other than decorative vegetation, not complying with Section 806.4shall comply with Sections 807.5.1through 807.5.6of theFire Code of New York State.

subsections.title: [F]806.4Acceptance criteria and reports.
subsections.content: Where required to exhibit improved fire performance, curtains, draperies, fabric hangings and similar combustible decorative materials suspended from walls or ceilings shall be tested by anapproved agencyand meet the flame propagation performance criteria of Test 1 or 2, as appropriate, of NFPA 701, or exhibit a maximum heat release rate of 100 kW when tested in accordance with NFPA 289, using the 20 kW ignition source. Reports of test results shall be prepared in accordance with the test method used and furnished to thebuilding officialupon request.

subsections.title: [F]806.5Foam plastic.
subsections.content: Foam plastic used astrimin any occupancy shall comply with Section 2604.2.

subsections.title: [F]806.6Pyroxylin plastic.
subsections.content: Imitation leather or other material consisting of or coated with a pyroxylin or similarly hazardous base shall not be used in Group A occupancies.

subsections.title: [F]806.7Interior trim.
subsections.content: Material, other than foam plastic used as interiortrim, shall have a minimum Class C flame spread andsmoke-developed indexwhen tested in accordance with ASTM E84or UL 723, as described in Section 803.1.2. Combustibletrim, excluding handrails and guardrails, shall not exceed 10 percent of the specific wall or ceiling area to which it is attached.

subsections.title: [F]806.8Interior floor-wall base.
subsections.content: Interior floor-wall basethat is 6 inches (152 mm) or less in height shall be tested in accordance with Section 804.2and shall be not less than Class II. Where a Class I floor finish is required, the floor-wall base shall be Class I.

subsections.title: 807.1Insulation.
subsections.content: Thermal and acoustical insulation shall comply with Section 720.

subsections.title: 808.1Acoustical ceiling systems.
subsections.content: The quality, design, fabrication and erection of metal suspension systems for acoustical tile and lay-in panel ceilings in buildings or structures shall conform to generally accepted engineering practice, the provisions of this chapter and other applicable requirements of this code.

subsubsections.title: 808.1.1Materials and installation.
subsubsections.content: Acoustical materials complying with theinterior finishrequirements of Section 803shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations and applicable provisions for applyinginterior finish.

chapter: CHAPTER 9 FIRE PROTECTION AND LIFE SAFETY SYSTEMS

subsections.title: 901.1Scope.
subsections.content: The provisions of this chapter shall specify where fire protection and life safety systems are required and shall apply to the design, installation and operation offire protection systems.

subsections.title: 901.2Fire protection systems.
subsections.content: Fire protection systemsshall be installed, repaired, operated and maintained in accordance with this code and theFire Code of New York State.

subsections.title: 901.3Modifications.
subsections.content: Persons shall not remove or modify anyfire protection systeminstalled or maintained under the provisions of this code or theFire Code of New York Statewithout approval by thebuilding official.

subsections.title: 901.4Threads.
subsections.content: Threads provided for fire department connections to sprinkler systems, standpipes, yard hydrants or any other fire hose connection shall be compatible with the connections used by the local fire department.

subsections.title: 901.5Acceptance tests.
subsections.content: Fire protection systemsshall be tested in accordance with the requirements of this code and theFire Code of New York State. Where required, the tests shall be conducted in the presence of thebuilding official. Tests required by this code, theFire Code of New York Stateand the standards listed in this code shall be conducted at the expense of the owner or the owner’s authorized agent. It shall be unlawful to occupy portions of a structure until the requiredfire protection systemswithin that portion of the structure have been tested andapproved.

subsections.title: 901.6Supervisory service.
subsections.content: Where required,fire protection systemsshall be monitored by an approved supervising station in accordance with NFPA 72.

subsubsections.title: 901.6.1Automatic sprinkler systems.
subsubsections.content: Automatic sprinkler systemsshall be monitored by anapprovedsupervising station.

subsubsections.title: [F]901.6.2Integrated testing.
subsubsections.content: Where two or more fire protection or life safety systems are interconnected, the intended response of subordinate fire protection and life safety systems shall be verified when required testing of the initiating system is conducted. In addition, integrated testing shall be performed in accordance with Sections 901.6.2.1and 901.6.2.2.

subsubsections.title: 901.6.3Fire alarm systems.
subsubsections.content: Fire alarm systems required by the provisions of Section 907.2of this code and Sections 907.2and 907.9of theFire Code of New York Stateshall be monitored by anapprovedsupervising station in accordance with Section 907.6.6of this code.

subsubsections.title: 901.6.4Group H.
subsubsections.content: Supervision and monitoring of emergency alarm, detection and automatic fire-extinguishing systems in Group H occupancies shall be in accordance with theFire Code of New York State.

subsections.title: 901.7Fire areas.
subsections.content: Where buildings, or portions thereof, are divided intofire areasso as not to exceed the limits established for requiring afire protection systemin accordance with this chapter, suchfire areasshall be separated byfire wallsconstructed in accordance with Section 706, fire barriers constructed in accordance with Section 707, orhorizontal assembliesconstructed in accordance with Section 711, or a combination thereof having a fire-resistance rating of not less than that determined in accordance with Section 707.3.10.

sections.section: SECTION BC 902 FIRE PUMP AND RISER ROOM SIZE

subsections.title: [F]902.1Pump and riser room size.
subsections.content: Where provided, fire pump rooms andautomatic sprinkler systemriser rooms shall be designed with adequate space for all equipment necessary for the installation, as defined by the manufacturer, with sufficient working room around the stationary equipment. Clearances around equipment to elements of permanent construction, including other installed equipment and appliances, shall be sufficient to allow inspection, service, repair or replacement without removing such elements of permanent construction or disabling the function of a required fire-resistance-rated assembly. Fire pump andautomatic sprinkler systemriser rooms shall be provided with doors and unobstructed passageways large enough to allow removal of the largest piece of equipment.

subsubsections.title: [F]902.1.1Access.
subsubsections.content: Automatic sprinkler system risers, fire pumps and controllers shall be provided with ready access. Where located in a fire pump room or automatic sprinkler system riser room, the door shall be permitted to be locked provided that the key is available at all times.

subsubsections.title: [F]902.1.2Marking on access doors.
subsubsections.content: Access doors for automatic sprinkler system riser rooms and fire pump rooms shall be labeled with an approved sign. The lettering shall be in contrasting color to the background. Letters shall have a minimum height of 2 inches (51 mm) with a minimum stroke of3/8inch (10 mm).

subsubsections.title: [F]902.1.3Environment.
subsubsections.content: Automatic sprinkler system riser rooms and fire pump rooms shall be maintained at a temperature of not less than 40°F (4°C). Heating units shall be permanently installed.

subsubsections.title: [F]902.1.4Lighting.
subsubsections.content: Permanently installed artificial illumination shall be provided in the automatic sprinkler system riser rooms and fire pump rooms.

subsections.title: [F]903.1General.
subsections.content: Automatic sprinkler systemsshall comply with this section.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.1.1Alternative protection.
subsubsections.content: Alternativeautomatic fire-extinguishing systemscomplying with Section 904shall be permitted instead of automatic sprinkler protection where recognized by the applicable standard andapprovedby the fire code official.

subsections.title: [F]903.2Where required.
subsections.content: Approvedautomatic sprinkler systemsin new buildings and structures shall be provided in the locations described in Sections 903.2.1through 903.2.12.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.2.1Group A.
subsubsections.content: Anautomatic sprinkler systemshall be provided throughout buildings and portions thereof used as Group A occupancies as provided in this section.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.2.2Ambulatory care facilities.
subsubsections.content: Anautomatic sprinkler systemshall be installed throughout the entire floor containing anambulatory care facilitywhere either of the following conditions exist at any time:

subsubsections.title: [F]903.2.3Group E.
subsubsections.content: Anautomatic sprinkler systemshall be provided for Group E occupancies as follows:

subsubsections.title: [F]903.2.4Group F-1.
subsubsections.content: Anautomatic sprinkler systemshall be provided throughout all buildings containing a Group F-1 occupancy where one of the following conditions exists:

subsubsections.title: [F]903.2.5Group H.
subsubsections.content: Automatic sprinkler systemsshall be provided in high-hazard occupancies as required in Sections 903.2.5.1through 903.2.5.3.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.2.6Group I.
subsubsections.content: Anautomatic sprinkler systemshall be provided throughout buildings with a Group Ifire area.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.2.7Group M.
subsubsections.content: Anautomatic sprinkler systemshall be provided throughout buildings containing a Group M occupancy where one of the following conditions exists:

subsubsections.title: [F]903.2.8Group R.
subsubsections.content: Anautomatic sprinkler systeminstalled in accordance with Section 903.3shall be provided throughout all buildings with a Group Rfire area.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.2.9Group S-1.
subsubsections.content: Anautomatic sprinkler systemshall be provided throughout all buildings containing a Group S-1 occupancy where one of the following conditions exists:

subsubsections.title: [F]903.2.10Group S-2 enclosed parking garages.
subsubsections.content: Anautomatic sprinkler systemshall be provided throughout buildings classified as enclosed parking garages in accordance with Section 406.6where either of the following conditions exists:

subsubsections.title: [F]903.2.11Specific building areas and hazards.
subsubsections.content: In all occupancies other than Group U, anautomatic sprinkler systemshall be installed for building design or hazards in the locations set forth in Sections 903.2.11.1through 903.2.11.6.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.2.12During construction.
subsubsections.content: Automatic sprinkler systemsrequired during construction,alterationand demolition operations shall be provided in accordance with Chapter 33of theFire Code of New York State.

subsections.title: [F]903.3Installation requirements.
subsections.content: Automatic sprinkler systemsshall be designed and installed in accordance with Sections 903.3.1through 903.3.8.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.3.1Standards.
subsubsections.content: Sprinkler systems shall be designed and installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1unless otherwise permitted by Sections 903.3.1.2and 903.3.1.3and other chapters of this code, as applicable.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.3.2Quick-response and residential sprinklers.
subsubsections.content: Whereautomatic sprinkler systemsare required by this code, quick-response or residential automatic sprinklers shall be installed in all of the following areas in accordance with Section 903.3.1and their listings:

subsubsections.title: [F]903.3.3Obstructed locations.
subsubsections.content: Automatic sprinklers shall be installed with regard to obstructions that will delay activation or obstruct the water distribution patternand shall be in accordance with the applicableautomatic sprinkler systemstandard that is being used. Automatic sprinklers shall be installed in or under covered kiosks,displays, booths, concession stands, or equipment that exceeds 4 feet (1219 mm) in width. Not less than a 3-foot (914 mm) clearance shall be maintained between automatic sprinklers and the top of piles of combustible fibers.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.3.4Actuation.
subsubsections.content: Automatic sprinkler systemsshall be automatically actuated unless specifically provided for in this code.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.3.5Water supplies.
subsubsections.content: Water supplies forautomatic sprinkler systemsshall comply with this section and the standards referenced in Section 903.3.1. The potable water supply shall be protected against backflow in accordance with the requirements of this section and thePlumbing Code of New York State. For connections to public waterworks systems, the water supply test used for design of fire protection systems shall be adjusted to account for seasonal and daily pressure fluctuations based on information from the water supply authority and as approved by the fire code official.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.3.6Hose threads.
subsubsections.content: Fire hose threads and fittings used in connection withautomatic sprinkler systemsshall be as prescribed by the fire code official.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.3.7Fire department connections.
subsubsections.content: Fire department connections forautomatic sprinkler systemsshall be installed in accordance with Section 912.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.3.8Limited area sprinkler systems.
subsubsections.content: Limited area sprinkler systems shall be in accordance with the standards listed in Section 903.3.1except as provided in Sections 903.3.8.1through 903.3.8.5.

subsections.title: [F]903.4Sprinkler system supervision and alarms.
subsections.content: Valves controlling the water supply forautomatic sprinkler systems, pumps, tanks, water levels and temperatures, critical air pressures and waterflow switches on all sprinkler systems shall be electrically supervised by alistedfire alarm control unit.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.4.1Monitoring.
subsubsections.content: Alarm, supervisory and trouble signals shall be distinctly different and shall be automatically transmitted to anapprovedsupervising station or, whereapprovedby the fire code official, shall sound an audible signal at aconstantly attended location.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.4.2Alarms.
subsubsections.content: An approved audible device, located on the exterior of the building in an approved location, shall be connected to eachautomatic sprinkler system. Such sprinkler waterflow alarm devices shall be activated by water flow equivalent to the flow of a single sprinkler of the smallest orifice size installed in the system. Where a fire alarm system is installed, actuation of theautomatic sprinkler systemshall actuate the building fire alarm system.

subsubsections.title: [F]903.4.3Floor control valves.
subsubsections.content: Approvedsupervised indicating control valves shall be provided at the point of connection to the riser on each floor in high-rise buildings.

subsections.title: [F]903.5Testing and maintenance.
subsections.content: Sprinkler systems shall be tested and maintained in accordance with theFire Code of New York State.

subsections.title: [F]904.1General.
subsections.content: Automatic fire-extinguishing systems, other thanautomatic sprinkler systems, shall be designed, installed, inspected, tested and maintained in accordance with the provisions of this section and the applicable referenced standards.

subsections.title: [F]904.2Where permitted.
subsections.content: Automatic fire-extinguishing systems installed as an alternative to the requiredautomatic sprinkler systemsof Section 903shall beapprovedby the fire code official.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.2.1Restriction on using automatic sprinkler system exceptions or reductions.
subsubsections.content: Automatic fire-extinguishing systems shall not be considered alternatives for the purposes of exceptions or reductions allowed forautomatic sprinkler systemsor by other requirements of this code.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.2.2Commercial hood and duct systems.
subsubsections.content: Each required commercial kitchen exhaust hood and duct system required by Section 607of theFire Code of New York Stateor Chapter 5of theMechanical Code of New York Stateto have a Type I hood shall be protected with an approved automatic fire-extinguishing system installed in accordance with this code.

subsections.title: [F]904.3Installation.
subsections.content: Automatic fire-extinguishing systems shall be installed in accordance with this section.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.3.1Electrical wiring.
subsubsections.content: Electrical wiring shall be in accordance with NFPA 70.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.3.2Actuation.
subsubsections.content: Automatic fire-extinguishing systems shall be automatically actuated and provided with a manual means of actuation in accordance with Section 904.11.1. Where more than one hazard could be simultaneously involved in fire due to their proximity, all hazards shall be protected by a single system designed to protect all hazards that could become involved.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.3.3System interlocking.
subsubsections.content: Automatic equipment interlocks with fuel shutoffs, ventilation controls, door closers, window shutters, conveyor openings, smoke and heat vents and other features necessary for proper operation of the fire-extinguishing system shall be provided as required by the design and installation standard utilized for the hazard.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.3.4Alarms and warning signs.
subsubsections.content: Where alarms are required to indicate the operation of automatic fire-extinguishing systems, distinctive audible and visible alarms and warning signs shall be provided to warn of pending agent discharge. Where exposure to automatic-extinguishing agents poses a hazard to persons and a delay is required to ensure the evacuation of occupants before agent discharge, a separate warning signal shall be provided to alert occupants once agent discharge has begun. Audible signals shall be in accordance with Section 907.5.2.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.3.5Monitoring.
subsubsections.content: Where a building fire alarm system is installed, automatic fire-extinguishing systems shall be monitored by the building fire alarm system in accordance with NFPA 72.

subsections.title: [F]904.4Inspection and testing.
subsections.content: Automatic fire-extinguishing systems shall be inspected and tested in accordance with the provisions of this section prior to acceptance.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.4.1Inspection.
subsubsections.content: Prior to conducting final acceptance tests, all of the following items shall be inspected:

subsubsections.title: [F]904.4.2Alarm testing.
subsubsections.content: Notification appliances, connections to fire alarm systems and connections toapprovedsupervising stations shall be tested in accordance with this section and Section 907to verify proper operation.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.4.3Monitor testing.
subsubsections.content: Connections to protected premises and supervising station fire alarm systems shall be tested to verify proper identification and retransmission of alarms from automatic fire-extinguishing systems.

subsections.title: [F]904.5Wet-chemical systems.
subsections.content: Wet-chemical extinguishing systems shall be installed, maintained, periodically inspected and tested in accordance with NFPA 17Aand their listing. Records of inspections and testing shall be maintained.

subsections.title: [F]904.6Dry-chemical systems.
subsections.content: Dry-chemical extinguishing systems shall be installed, maintained, periodically inspected and tested in accordance with NFPA 17and their listing. Records of inspections and testing shall be maintained.

subsections.title: [F]904.7Foam systems.
subsections.content: Foam-extinguishing systems shall be installed, maintained, periodically inspected and tested in accordance with NFPA 11and NFPA 16and their listing. Records of inspections and testing shall be maintained.

subsections.title: [F]904.8Carbon dioxide systems.
subsections.content: Carbon dioxide extinguishing systems shall be installed, maintained, periodically inspected and tested in accordance with NFPA 12and their listing. Records of inspections and testing shall be maintained.

subsections.title: [F]904.9Halon systems.
subsections.content: Halogenated extinguishing systems shall be installed, maintained, periodically inspected and tested in accordance with NFPA 12Aand their listing. Records of inspections and testing shall be maintained.

subsections.title: [F]904.10Clean-agent systems.
subsections.content: Clean-agent fire-extinguishing systems shall be installed, maintained, periodically inspected and tested in accordance with NFPA 2001and their listing. Records of inspections and testing shall be maintained.

subsections.title: [F]904.11Automatic water mist systems.
subsections.content: Automatic water mist systemsshall be permitted in applications that are consistent with the applicable listing or approvals and shall comply with Sections 904.11.1through 904.11.3.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.11.1Design and installation requirements.
subsubsections.content: Automatic water mist systemsshall be designed and installed in accordance with Sections 904.11.1.1through 904.11.1.4.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.11.2Water mist system supervision and alarms.
subsubsections.content: Supervision and alarms shall be provided as required forautomatic sprinkler systemsin accordance with Section 903.4.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.11.3Testing and maintenance.
subsubsections.content: Automatic water mist systemsshall be tested and maintained in accordance with theFire Code of New York State.

subsections.title: [F]904.12Commercial cooking systems.
subsections.content: The automatic fire-extinguishing system for commercial cooking systems shall be of a type recognized for protection of commercial cooking equipment and exhaust systems of the type and arrangement protected. Preengineered automatic dry- and wet-chemical extinguishing systems shall be tested in accordance with UL 300andlistedandlabeledfor the intended application. Other types of automatic fire-extinguishing systems shall belistedandlabeledfor specific use as protection for commercial cooking operations. The system shall beinstalled in accordance with this code, NFPA 96, its listingand the manufacturer’s installation instructions. Automatic fire-extinguishing systems of the following types shall be installed in accordance with the referenced standard indicated, as follows:

subsubsections.title: [F]904.12.1Manual system operation.
subsubsections.content: A manual actuation device shall be located at or near ameans of egressfrom the cooking area not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) and not more than 20 feet (6096 mm) from the kitchen exhaust system. The manual actuation device shall be installed not more than 48 inches (1200 mm) or less than 42 inches (1067 mm) above the floor and shall clearly identify the hazard protected. The manual actuation shall require a maximum force of 40 pounds (178 N) and a maximum movement of 14 inches (356 mm) to actuate the fire suppression system.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.12.2System interconnection.
subsubsections.content: The actuation of the fire suppression system shall automatically shut down the fuel or electrical power supply to the cooking equipment. The fuel and electrical supply reset shall be manual.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.12.3Carbon dioxide systems.
subsubsections.content: Where carbon dioxide systems are used, there shall be a nozzle at the top of the ventilating duct. Additional nozzles that are symmetrically arranged to give uniform distribution shall be installed within vertical ducts exceeding 20 feet (6096 mm) and horizontal ducts exceeding 50 feet (15 240 mm).Dampersshall be installed at either the top or the bottom of the duct and shall be arranged to operate automatically upon activation of the fire-extinguishing system. Where thedamperis installed at the top of the duct, the top nozzle shall be immediately below thedamper. Automatic carbon dioxide fire-extinguishing systems shall be sufficiently sized to protect against all hazards venting through a common duct simultaneously.

subsubsections.title: [F]904.12.4Special provisions for automatic sprinkler systems.
subsubsections.content: Automatic sprinkler systemsprotecting commercial-type cooking equipment shall be supplied from a separate, indicating-type control valve that is identified.Access to the control valve shall be provided.

subsections.title: [F]904.13Domestic cooking systems.
subsections.content: Cooktops and ranges installed in the following occupancies shall be protected in accordance with Section 904.13.1:

subsubsections.title: [F]904.13.1Protection from fire.
subsubsections.content: Cooktops and ranges shall be protected in accordance with Section 904.13.1.1or 904.13.1.2.

subsections.title: [F]904.14Aerosol fire-extinguishing systems.
subsections.content: Aerosol fire-extinguishing systems shall be installed, periodically inspected, tested and maintained in accordance with Sections 901and 904.4, NFPA 2010, and in accordance with their listing.

subsections.title: [NY]905.1General.
subsections.content: Standpipe systems shall be provided in new buildings and structures in accordance with Sections 905.2through 905.11. In buildings used for high-piled combustible storage, fire protection shall be in accordance with Chapter 32of theFire Code of New York State.

subsections.title: [NY]905.2Installation and initial testing standard.
subsections.content: Standpipe system installation and initial testing shall be performed in accordance with this section and NFPA 14. Flow testing of standpipes shall not be waived. Fire department connections for standpipe systems shall be in accordance with Section 912.

subsections.title: [F]905.3Required installations.
subsections.content: Standpipe systems shall be installed where required by Sections 905.3.1through 905.3.8. Standpipe systems are allowed to be combined with automatic sprinkler systems.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.3.1Height.
subsubsections.content: Class III standpipe systems shall beinstalled throughout buildings where any of the following conditions exist:

subsubsections.title: [F]905.3.2Group A.
subsubsections.content: Class I automatic wet standpipes shall be provided in nonsprinklered Group A buildings having anoccupant loadexceeding 1,000 persons.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.3.3Covered and open mall buildings.
subsubsections.content: Covered mall and open mall buildings shall be equipped throughout with a standpipe system where required by Section 905.3.1. Mall buildings not required to be equipped with a standpipe system by Section 905.3.1shall be equipped with Class I hose connections connected to theautomatic sprinkler systemsized to deliver water at 250 gallons per minute (946.4 L/min) at the hydraulically most remote hose connection while concurrently supplying the automatic sprinkler system demand. The standpipe system shall be designed to not exceed a 50 pounds per square inch (psi) (345 kPa) residual pressure loss with a flow of 250 gallons per minute (946.4 L/min) from the fire department connection to the hydraulically most remote hose connection. Hose connections shall be provided at each of the following locations:

subsubsections.title: [F]905.3.4Stages.
subsubsections.content: Stages greater than 1,000 square feet (93 m2) in area shall be equipped with a Class III wet standpipe system with 11/2-inch and 21/2-inch (38 mm and 64 mm) hose connections on each side of the stage.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.3.5Underground buildings.
subsubsections.content: Underground buildings shall be equipped throughout with a Class I automatic wet or manual wet standpipe system.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.3.6Helistops and heliports.
subsubsections.content: Buildings with a rooftophelistoporheliportshall be equipped with a Class I or III standpipe system extended to the roof level on which thehelistoporheliportis located in accordance with Section 2007.5of theFire Code of New York State.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.3.7Marinas and boatyards.
subsubsections.content: Standpipes in marinas and boatyards shall comply with Chapter 36of theFire Code of New York State.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.3.8Rooftop gardens and landscaped roofs.
subsubsections.content: Buildings or structures that have rooftop gardens or landscaped roofs and that are equipped with a standpipe system shall have the standpipe system extended to the roof level on which the rooftop garden or landscaped roof is located.

subsections.title: [F]905.4Location of Class I standpipe hose connections.
subsections.content: Class I standpipe hose connections shall be provided in all of the following locations:

subsubsections.title: [F]905.4.1Protection.
subsubsections.content: Risers and laterals of Class I standpipe systems not located within aninterior exit stairwayshall be protected by a degree offire resistanceequal to that required for vertical enclosures in the building in which they are located.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.4.2Interconnection.
subsubsections.content: In buildings where more than one standpipe is provided, the standpipes shall be interconnected in accordance with NFPA 14.

subsections.title: [F]905.5Location of Class II standpipe hose connections.
subsections.content: Class II standpipe hose connections located so that all portions of the building are within 30 feet (9144 mm) of a nozzleattached to 100 feet (30 480 mm) of hose. Class II standpipe hose connections shall be located where they will haveready access.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.5.1Groups A-1 and A-2.
subsubsections.content: In Group A-1 and A-2 occupancies havingoccupant loadsexceeding 1,000 persons, hose connections shall be located on each side of any stage, on each side of the rear of the auditorium, on each side of the balcony and on each tier of dressing rooms.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.5.2Protection.
subsubsections.content: Fire-resistance-rated protection of risers and laterals of Class II standpipe systems is not required.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.5.3Class II system 1-inch hose.
subsubsections.content: A minimum 1-inch (25 mm) hose shall be allowed to be used for hose stations in light-hazard occupancies where investigated andlistedfor this service and whereapprovedby the fire code official.

subsections.title: [F]905.6Location of Class III standpipe hose connections.
subsections.content: Class III standpipe systems shall have hose connections located as required for Class I standpipes in Section 905.4and shall have Class II hose connections as required in Section 905.5.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.6.1Protection.
subsubsections.content: Risers and laterals of Class III standpipe systems shall be protected as required for Class I systems in accordance with Section 905.4.1.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.6.2Interconnection.
subsubsections.content: In buildings where more than one Class III standpipe is provided, the standpipes shall be interconnected in accordance with NFPA 14.

subsections.title: [F]905.7Cabinets.
subsections.content: Cabinets containing fire-fighting equipment such as standpipes, fire hoses, fire extinguishers or fire department valves shall not be blocked from use or obscured from view.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.7.1Cabinet equipment identification.
subsubsections.content: Cabinets shall be identified in anapprovedmanner by a permanently attached sign with letters not less than 2 inches (51 mm) high in a color that contrasts with the background color, indicating the equipment contained therein.

subsubsections.title: [F]905.7.2Locking cabinet doors.
subsubsections.content: Cabinets shall be unlocked.

subsections.title: [F]905.8Dry standpipes.
subsections.content: Dry standpipes shall not be installed.

subsections.title: [F]905.9Valve supervision.
subsections.content: Valves controlling water supplies shall be supervised in the open position so that a change in the normal position of the valve will generate a supervisory signal at the supervising station required by Section 903.4. Where a fire alarm system is provided, a signal shall be transmitted to the control unit.

subsections.title: [F]905.10During construction.
subsections.content: Standpipe systems required during construction and demolition operations shall be provided in accordance with Section 3311.

subsections.title: [F]905.11Locking standpipe outlet caps.
subsections.content: Thefire code officialis authorized to require locking caps on the outlets on dry standpipes where the responding fire department carries key wrenches for the removal that are compatible with locking FDC connection caps.

subsections.title: [F]906.1Where required.
subsections.content: Portable fire extinguishers shall be installed in all of the following locations:

subsections.title: [F]906.2General requirements.
subsections.content: Portable fire extinguishers shall be selected and installed in accordance with this section and NFPA 10.

subsections.title: [F]906.3Size and distribution.
subsections.content: The size and distribution of portable fire extinguishers shall be in accordance with Sections 906.3.1through 906.3.4.

subsubsections.title: [F]906.3.1Class A fire hazards.
subsubsections.content: The minimum sizes and distribution of portable fire extinguishers for occupancies that involve primarily Class A fire hazards shall comply with Table 906.3(1).

subsubsections.title: [F]906.3.2Class B fire hazards.
subsubsections.content: Portable fire extinguishers for occupancies involving flammable or combustible liquids with depths less than or equal to 0.25-inch (6.4 mm) shall be selected and placed in accordance with Table 906.3(2).

subsubsections.title: [F]906.3.3Class C fire hazards.
subsubsections.content: Portable fire extinguishers for Class C fire hazards shall be selected and placed on the basis of the anticipated Class A or B hazard.

subsubsections.title: [F]906.3.4Class D fire hazards.
subsubsections.content: Portable fire extinguishers for occupancies involving combustible metals shall be selected and placed in accordance with NFPA 10.

subsections.title: [F]906.4Cooking equipment fires.
subsections.content: Fire extinguishers provided for the protection of cooking equipment shall be of anapprovedtype compatible with the automaticfire-extinguishing system agent. Cooking equipment involving solid fuels or vegetable or animal oils and fats shall be protected by a Class K-rated portable extinguisher in accordance with Sections 906.1, Item 2, 906.4.1and 906.4.2of theFire Code of New York State, as applicable.

subsections.title: [F]906.5Conspicuous location.
subsections.content: Portable fire extinguishers shall be located in conspicuous locations where they willhaveready accessand be immediately available for use.These locations shall be along normal paths of travel, unless the fire code official determines that the hazard posed indicates the need for placement away from normal paths of travel.

subsections.title: [F]906.6Unobstructed and unobscured.
subsections.content: Portable fire extinguishers shall not be obstructed or obscured from view. In rooms or areas in which visual obstruction cannot be completely avoided, means shall be provided to indicate the locations of extinguishers.

subsections.title: [F]906.7Hangers and brackets.
subsections.content: Hand-held portable fire extinguishers, not housed in cabinets, shall be installed on the hangers or brackets supplied. Hangers or brackets shall be securely anchored to the mounting surface in accordance with the manufacturer’s installation instructions.

subsections.title: [F]906.8Cabinets.
subsections.content: Cabinets used to house portable fire extinguishers shall not be locked.

subsections.title: [F]906.9Extinguisher installation.
subsections.content: The installation of portable fire extinguishers shall be in accordance with Sections 906.9.1through 906.9.3.

subsubsections.title: [F]906.9.1Extinguishers weighing 40 pounds or less.
subsubsections.content: Portable fire extinguishers having a gross weight not exceeding 40 pounds (18 kg) shall be installed so that their tops are not more than 5 feet (1524 mm) above the floor.

subsubsections.title: [F]906.9.2Extinguishers weighing more than 40 pounds.
subsubsections.content: Hand-held portable fire extinguishers having a gross weight exceeding 40 pounds (18 kg) shall be installed so that their tops are not more than 3.5 feet (1067 mm) above the floor.

subsubsections.title: [F]906.9.3Floor clearance.
subsubsections.content: The clearance between the floor and the bottom of installed hand-held portable fire extinguishers shall be not less than 4 inches (102 mm).

subsections.title: [F]906.10Wheeled units.
subsections.content: Wheeled fire extinguishers shall be conspicuously located in a designated location.

sections.section: SECTION BC 907 FIRE ALARM AND DETECTION SYSTEMS

subsections.title: [F]907.1General.
subsections.content: This section covers the application, installation, performance and maintenance of fire alarm systems and their components.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.1.1Construction documents.
subsubsections.content: Construction documentsfor fire alarm systems shall be of sufficient clarity to indicate the location, nature and extent of the work proposed and show in detail that it will conform to the provisions of this code, theFire Code of New York Stateand relevant laws, ordinances, rules and regulations, as determined by the fire code official.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.1.2Fire alarm shop drawings.
subsubsections.content: Shop drawingsfor fire alarm systems shall be prepared in accordance with NFPA 72and submitted for review and approval prior tosystem installation.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.1.3Equipment.
subsubsections.content: Systems and components shall belistedandapprovedfor the purpose for which they are installed.

subsections.title: [F]907.2Where required—new buildings and structures.
subsections.content: Anapprovedfire alarm system installed in accordance with the provisions of this code and NFPA 72shall be provided in new buildings and structures in accordance with Sections 907.2.1through 907.2.23and provide occupant notification in accordance with Section 907.5, unless other requirements are provided by another section of this code.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.1Group A.
subsubsections.content: A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5shall be installed in Group A occupancies where the occupant load due to the assemblyoccupancy is 300 or more, or where the Group A occupant load is more than 100 persons above or below thelowest level of exit discharge. Group A occupancies not separated from one another in accordance with Section 707.3.10shall be considered as a single occupancy for the purposes of applying this section. Portions of Group E occupancies occupied for assembly purposes shall be provided with a fire alarm system as required for the Group E occupancy.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.2Group B.
subsubsections.content: A manual fire alarm system shall be installed in Group B occupancies where one of the following conditions exists:

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.3Group E.
subsubsections.content: A manual fire alarm system that initiates the occupant notification signal utilizing an emergency voice/alarm communication system meeting the requirements of Section 907.5.2.2and installed in accordance with Section 907.6shall be installed in Group E occupancies. Whereautomatic sprinkler systemsor smoke detectors are installed, such systems or detectors shall be connected to the building fire alarm system.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.4Group F.
subsubsections.content: A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5shall be installed in Group F occupancies where both of the following conditions exist:

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.5Group H.
subsubsections.content: A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5shall be installed in Group H-5 occupancies and in occupancies used for the manufacture of organic coatings. An automatic smoke detection system shall be installed for highly toxic gases, organic peroxides and oxidizers in accordance with Chapters 60, 62and 63, respectively, of theFire Code of New York State.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.6Group I.
subsubsections.content: A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5shall be installed in Group I occupancies. An automatic smoke detection system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5shall be provided in accordance with Sections 907.2.6.1, 907.2.6.2and 907.2.6.3.3.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.7Group M.
subsubsections.content: A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5shall be installed in Group M occupancies where one of the following conditions exists:

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.8Group R-1.
subsubsections.content: Fire alarm systems and smoke alarms shall be installed in Group R-1 occupancies as required in Sections 907.2.8.1through 907.2.8.3.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.9Group R-2.
subsubsections.content: Fire alarm systems and smoke alarms shall be installed in Group R-2 occupancies as required in Sections 907.2.9.1through 907.2.9.3.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.10Single- and multiple-station smoke alarms.
subsubsections.content: Listedsingle- and multiple-station smoke alarms complying with UL 217shall be installed in accordance with Sections 907.2.10.1through 907.2.10.7and NFPA 72.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.11Special amusement buildings.
subsubsections.content: An automatic smoke detection system shall be provided inspecial amusement buildingsin accordance with Sections 907.2.11.1through 907.2.11.3.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.12High-rise buildings.
subsubsections.content: High-rise buildings shall be provided with an automatic smoke detection system in accordance with Section 907.2.12.1, a fire department communication system in accordance with Section 907.2.12.2and an emergency voice/alarm communication system in accordance with Section 907.5.2.2.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.13Atriums connecting more than two stories.
subsubsections.content: A fire alarm system shall be installed in occupancies with an atrium that connects more than twostories, with smoke detection installed in locations required by a rational analysis in Section 909.4and in accordance with the system operation requirements in Section 909.17. The system shall be activated in accordance with Section 907.5. Such occupancies in Group A, E or M shall be provided with an emergency voice/alarm communication system complying with the requirements of Section 907.5.2.2.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.14High-piled combustible storage areas.
subsubsections.content: An automatic smoke detection system shall be installed throughout high-piled combustible storage areas where required by Section 3206.5of theFire Code of New York State.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.15Aerosol storage uses.
subsubsections.content: Aerosol product rooms and general-purpose warehouses containing aerosol products shall be provided with anapprovedmanual firealarm system where required by theFire Code of New York State.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.16Lumber, wood structural panel and veneer mills.
subsubsections.content: Lumber, wood structural panel and veneer mills shall be provided with a manual fire alarm system.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.17Underground buildings with smoke control systems.
subsubsections.content: Where a smoke control system is installed in an underground building in accordance with this code, automatic smoke detectors shall be provided in accordance with Section 907.2.17.1.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.18Deep underground buildings.
subsubsections.content: Where the lowest level of a structure is more than 60 feet (18 288 mm) below the finished floor of the lowestlevel of exit discharge, the structure shall be equipped throughout with a manual fire alarm system, including an emergency voice/alarm communication system installed in accordance with Section 907.5.2.2.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.19Covered and open mall buildings.
subsubsections.content: Where the total floor area exceeds 50,000 square feet (4645 m2) within either a covered mall building or within the perimeter line of an open mall building, an emergencyvoice/alarm communication system shall be provided. Access to emergency voice/alarm communication systems serving a mall, required or otherwise, shall be provided for the firedepartment. The system shall be provided in accordance with Section 907.5.2.2.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.20Residential aircraft hangars.
subsubsections.content: Not fewer than one single-station smoke alarm shall be installed within a residential aircraft hangar as defined in Chapter 2and shall be interconnected into the residential smoke alarm or other sounding device to provide an alarm that will be audible in all sleeping areas of thedwelling.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.2.21Airport traffic control towers.
subsubsections.content: An automatic smoke detection system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5shall be provided in airport control towers in accordance with Sections 907.2.21.1and 907.2.21.2.

subsubsections.title: [NY]907.2.22Battery rooms.
subsubsections.content: An automatic smoke detection system shall be installed in areas containingstationaryenergy storage systemsas required in Section 1206of theFire Code of New York State.

subsubsections.title: [NY]907.2.23Capacitor energy storage systems.
subsubsections.content: An automatic smoke detection system shall be installed in areas containingcapacitor energy storage systemsas required by Section 1206of theFire Code of New York State.

subsections.title: [F]907.3Fire safety functions.
subsections.content: Automatic fire detectors utilized for the purpose of performing fire safety functions shall be connected to the building’s fire alarm control unit where a fire alarm system is required by Section 907.2. Detectors shall, upon actuation, perform the intended function and activate the alarm notification appliances or activate a visible and audible supervisory signal at aconstantly attended location. In buildings not equipped with a fire alarm system, the automatic fire detector shall be powered by normal electrical service and, upon actuation, perform the intended function. The detectors shall be located in accordance with NFPA 72.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.3.1Duct smoke detectors.
subsubsections.content: Smoke detectors installed in ducts shall belistedfor the air velocity, temperature and humidity present in the duct. Duct smoke detectors shall be connected to the building's fire alarm control unit where a fire alarm system is required by Section 907.2. Activation of a duct smoke detector shall initiate a visible and audible supervisory signal at aconstantly attended locationand shall perform the intended fire safety function in accordance with this code and theMechanical Code of New York State. In facilities that are required to be monitored by a supervising station, duct smoke detectors shall report only as a supervisory signal and not as a fire alarm. They shall not be used as a substitute for required open area detection.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.3.2Special locking systems.
subsubsections.content: Where special locking systems are installed onmeans of egressdoors in accordance with Sections 1010.1.9.7or 1010.1.9.8, an automatic detection system shall be installed as required by that section.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.3.3Elevator emergency operation.
subsubsections.content: Automatic fire detectors installed for elevator emergency operation shall be installed in accordance with the provisions of ASME A17.1/CSA B44and NFPA 72.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.3.4Wiring.
subsubsections.content: The wiring to the auxiliary devices and equipment used to accomplish the fire safety functions shall be monitored for integrity in accordance with NFPA 72.

subsections.title: [F]907.4Initiating devices.
subsections.content: Where manual or automatic alarm initiation is required as part of a fire alarm system, the initiating devices shall be installed in accordance with Sections 907.4.1through 907.4.3.1.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.4.1Protection of fire alarm control unit.
subsubsections.content: In areas that are not continuously occupied, a single smoke detector shall be provided at the location of each fire alarm control unit, notification appliance circuit power extenders, and supervising station transmitting equipment.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.4.2Manual fire alarm boxes.
subsubsections.content: Where a manual fire alarm system is required by another section of this code, it shall be activated by fire alarm boxes installed in accordance with Sections 907.4.2.1through 907.4.2.6.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.4.3Automatic smoke detection.
subsubsections.content: Where an automatic smoke detection system is required it shall utilize smoke detectors unless ambient conditions prohibit such an installation. In spaces where smoke detectors cannot be utilized due to ambient conditions,approvedautomaticheat detectorsshall be permitted.

subsections.title: [F]907.5Occupant notification systems.
subsections.content: A fire alarm system shall annunciate at the fire alarm control unit and shall initiate occupant notification upon activation, in accordance with Sections 907.5.1through 907.5.2.3.3. Where a fire alarm system is required by another section of this code, it shall be activated by:

subsubsections.title: [F]907.5.1Presignal feature.
subsubsections.content: A presignal feature shall not be installed unlessapprovedby the fire code official. Where a presignal feature is provided, a signal shall be annunciated at aconstantly attended location approvedby thefire code officialso that occupant notification can be activated in the event of fire or other emergency.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.5.2Alarm notification appliances.
subsubsections.content: Alarm notification appliances shall be provided and shall belistedfor their purpose.

subsections.title: [F]907.6Installation and monitoring.
subsections.content: A fire alarm system shall be installed and monitored in accordance with Sections 907.6.1through 907.6.6.2and NFPA 72.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.6.1Wiring.
subsubsections.content: Wiring shall comply with the requirements of NFPA 70and NFPA 72. Wireless protection systems utilizing radio-frequency transmitting devices shall comply with the special requirements for supervision of low-power wireless systems in NFPA 72.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.6.2Power supply.
subsubsections.content: The primary and secondary power supply for the fire alarm system shall be provided in accordance with NFPA 72.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.6.3Initiating device identification.
subsubsections.content: The fire alarm system shall identify the specific initiating device address, location, device type, floor level where applicable and status including indication of normal, alarm, trouble and supervisory status, as appropriate.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.6.4Zones.
subsubsections.content: Each floor shall be zoned separately and a zone shall not exceed 22,500 square feet (2090 m2). The length of any zone shall not exceed 300 feet (91 440 mm) in any direction.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.6.5Access.
subsubsections.content: Access shall be provided to each fire alarm device and notification appliance for periodic inspection, maintenance and testing.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.6.6Monitoring.
subsubsections.content: Fire alarm systems required by this chapter or by theFire Code of New York Stateshall be monitored by anapprovedsupervising station in accordance with NFPA 72.

subsections.title: [F]907.7Acceptance tests and completion.
subsections.content: Upon completion of the installation, the fire alarm system and all fire alarm components shall be tested in accordance with NFPA 72.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.7.1Single- and multiple-station alarm devices.
subsubsections.content: When the installation of the alarm devices is complete, each device and interconnecting wiring for multiple-station alarm devices shall be tested in accordance with the smoke alarm provisions of NFPA 72.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.7.2Record of completion.
subsubsections.content: A record of completion in accordance with NFPA 72verifying that the system has been installed and tested in accordance with theapprovedplans and specifications shall be provided.

subsubsections.title: [F]907.7.3Instructions.
subsubsections.content: Operating, testing and maintenance instructions and record drawings (“as-builts”) and equipment specifications shall be provided at anapprovedlocation.

subsections.title: [NY]907.8Inspection, testing and maintenance.
subsections.content: The maintenance and testing schedules and procedures for fire alarm and fire detection systems shall be in accordance with Section 907.8of theFire Code of New York Stateand NFPA 72.

subsections.title: [F]908.1Group H occupancies.
subsections.content: Emergency alarms for the detection and notification of an emergency condition in Group H occupancies shall be provided in accordance with Section 415.5.

subsections.title: [F]908.2Group H-5 occupancy.
subsections.content: Emergency alarms for notification of an emergency condition in an HPM facility shall be provided as required in Section 415.11.3.5.

subsections.title: [F]909.1Scope and purpose.
subsections.content: This section applies to mechanical or passive smoke control systems where they are required by other provisions of this code. The purpose of this section is to establish minimum requirements for the design, installation and acceptance testing of smoke control systems that are intended to provide a tenable environment for the evacuation or relocation of occupants. These provisions are not intended for the preservation of contents, the timely restoration of operations or for assistance in fire suppression or overhaul activities. Smoke control systems regulated by this section serve a different purpose than the smoke- andheat-removal provisions found in Section 910. Mechanical smokecontrol systems shall not be considered exhaust systems under Chapter 5of theMechanical Code of New York State.

subsections.title: [F]909.2General design requirements.
subsections.content: Buildings, structures or parts thereof required by this code to have a smoke control system or systems shall have such systems designed in accordance with the applicable requirements of Section 909and the generally accepted and well-established principles of engineering relevant to the design. Theconstruction documentsshall include sufficient information and detail to adequately describe the elements of the design necessary for the proper implementation of the smoke control systems. These documents shall be accompanied by sufficient information and analysis to demonstrate compliance with these provisions.

subsections.title: [F]909.3Special inspection and test requirements.
subsections.content: In addition to the ordinary inspection and test requirements that buildings, structures and parts thereof are required to undergo, smoke control systems subject to the provisions of Section 909shall undergospecial inspectionsand tests sufficient to verify the proper commissioning of the smoke control design in its final installed condition. The design submission accompanying theconstruction documentsshall clearly detail procedures and methods to be used and the items subject to such inspections and tests. Such commissioning shall be in accordance with generally accepted engineering practice and, where possible, based on published standards for the particular testing involved. The special inspections and tests required by this section shall be conducted under the same terms in Section 1704.

subsections.title: [F]909.4Analysis.
subsections.content: A rational analysis supporting the types of smoke control systems to be employed, their methods of operation, the systems supporting them and the methods of construction to be utilized shall accompany the submittedconstruction documentsand shall include, but not be limited to, the items indicated in Sections 909.4.1through 909.4.7.

subsubsections.title: [F]909.4.1Stack effect.
subsubsections.content: The system shall be designed such that the maximum probable normal or reverse stack effect will not adversely interfere with the system’s capabilities. In determining the maximum probable stack effect, altitude, elevation, weather history and interior temperatures shall be used.

subsubsections.title: [F]909.4.2Temperature effect of fire.
subsubsections.content: Buoyancy and expansion caused by the design fire in accordance with Section 909.9shall be analyzed. The system shall be designed such that these effects do not adversely interfere with the system’s capabilities.

subsubsections.title: [F]909.4.3Wind effect.
subsubsections.content: The design shall consider the adverse effects of wind. Such consideration shall be consistent with the wind-loading provisions of Chapter 16.

subsubsections.title: [F]909.4.4HVAC systems.
subsubsections.content: The design shall consider the effects of the heating, ventilating and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems on both smoke and fire transport. The analysis shall include all permutations of systems status. The design shall consider the effects of the fire on the HVAC systems.

subsubsections.title: [F]909.4.5Climate.
subsubsections.content: The design shall consider the effects of low temperatures on systems, property and occupants. Air inlets and exhausts shall be located so as to prevent snow or ice blockage.

subsubsections.title: [F]909.4.6Duration of operation.
subsubsections.content: All portions of active or engineered smoke control systems shall be capable of continued operation after detection of the fire event for a period of not less than either 20 minutes or 1.5 times the calculated egress time, whichever is greater.

subsubsections.title: 909.4.7Smoke control system interaction.
subsubsections.content: The design shall consider the interaction effects of the operation of multiple smoke control systems for all design scenarios.

subsections.title: [F]909.5Smoke barrier construction.
subsections.content: Smoke barriersrequired for passive smoke control and a smoke control system using the pressurization method shall comply with Section 709. The maximum allowable leakage area shall be the aggregate area calculated using the following leakage area ratios:

subsubsections.title: [F]909.5.1Total leakage area.
subsubsections.content: Total leakage area of the barrier is the product of thesmoke barriergross area multiplied by the allowable leakage area ratio, plus the area of other openings such as gaps around doors and operable windows.

subsubsections.title: [F]909.5.2Testing of leakage area.
subsubsections.content: Compliance with the maximum total leakage area shall be determined by achieving the minimum air pressure difference across the barrier with the system in the smoke control mode for mechanical smoke control systems utilizing the pressurization method.
